AI didn’t just evolve— It redefined what’s possible, shaping industries with advancements that stretched across customer service, cybersecurity, and even medical research.\xa0 AI adoption is accelerating rapidly as companies look for new ways to increase efficiencies further and drive innovation.\\n\\nReflecting on another pivotal year for AI, here’s a look into the 8 biggest AI trends that made headlines in 2024.\\n\\n1\\\\. Generative AI: From Hype to Essential Business Tool\\n-------------------------------------------------------\\n\\n![Image 4](https://www.neudesic.com/wp-content/uploads/in-blog-2024-AI-recap_AI-usage-increase-1024x398.png)\\n\\nIn just one year, from 2023 to 2024, generative AI dramatically shifted from a phase of rapid experimentation to a period of essential integrations into business operations. Furthermore, [IDC’s global survey](https://blogs.microsoft.com/blog/2024/11/12/idcs-2024-ai-opportunity-study-top-five-ai-trends-to-watch/) of enterprise organizations found that generative AI adoption is rapidly expanding with usage figures jumping from 55% in 2023 to 75%. Across industries, businesses began to embed AI into their core operations —particularly generative AI, which has rapidly taken hold in marketing and sales functions, where text-based communications and personalization serve as key drivers. \xa0Companies in financial services, retail, and media have used generative AI to personalize customer experiences, reduce time-to-market, and streamline operations. In short, generative AI has transitioned from hype and proof-of-concept experiments to broader adoption, with companies emphasizing real-world implementations with tangible results.\\n\\n![Image 5](blob:http://localhost/ad49616dad180b71b08861433333c330)\\n\\nOpenAI’s ChatGPT played a key role in this surge. By December 2024, [ChatGPT reached 300 million weekly active users](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/12/04/openais-active-user-count-soars-to-300-million-people-per-week.html)—up from 200 million just four months prior. This explosive growth is a sign that generative AI is no longer a futuristic concept but an essential, versatile tool—one that’s quickly becoming more ingrained with our culture and society both professionally and personally—and it’s here to stay.\\n\\n2\\\\. Multimodal AI: Diverse Content from One Model\\n-------------------------------------------------\\n\\nAnother significant AI trend was the major advancements in multimodal AI—systems that understand and generate text, images, and audio from a single interface. Multimodal AI reduces the need for multiple specialized tools, making it easier for organizations to create and manage diverse content. Fun fact: the cover image of this blog was created using multimodal AI, courtesy of [Midjourney](https://www.midjourney.com/home).\\n\\nTwo major players, [OpenAI’s Sora](https://openai.com/index/learning-to-reason-with-llms/) and [Google’s Veo](https://deepmind.google/technologies/veo/veo-1/), captured the AI spotlight by providing impressive text-to-video capabilities. These tools promise to simplify content production for marketing, media, and education, allowing users to generate video content directly from a written prompt. The result? Faster production cycles and reduced creative bottlenecks.\\n\\n3\\\\. Reasoning AI: Solving Complex Problems\\n------------------------------------------\\n\\nOne of the most game-changing AI trends this year was the focus on building robust reasoning capabilities into AI systems. From new prompting methods to new model training techniques to new AI agent architectures, there have been many different approaches to building AI systems capable of solving increasingly complex tasks by iteratively planning, solving, and evaluating their work.\\n\\nModels with advanced reasoning capabilities, like \xa0[OpenAI’s o1](https://openai.com/index/introducing-openai-o1-preview/), can already solve complex problems using logical steps that are similar to how humans think before responding to difficult questions.\xa0These capabilities will continue to be useful in fields like science, coding, math, law and medicine, allowing models to compare contracts, generate code and execute multistep workflows.\\n\\nMicrosoft’s [Phi models](https://news.microsoft.com/source/features/ai/the-phi-3-small-language-models-with-big-potential/) demonstrated how smaller models, when trained on high-quality data, can improve model performance and reasoning. Meanwhile, Orca and [Orca 2](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/blog/orca-2-teaching-small-language-models-how-to-reason/?msockid=1dbcd2bacdc96a0e1328c686cc736b2f) showed how synthetic data for post-training could improve model performance, making small models as capable as much larger language models. These training techniques help smaller models perform better on specialized tasks. Making models faster, better and more specialized will help create new and more useful AI experiences.\\n\\n4\\\\. AI Agents: From Reactive to Proactive\\n-----------------------------------------\\n\\nAI agents are swiftly evolving and transcending across differing business types and industries. [AI Agents extend the ability of LLMs](https://www.neudesic.com/blog/ai-agent-systems/) by equipping the model with tools and enabling it to act on a user’s behalf. Nearly [70% of Fortune 500 companies](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/investor/events/fy-2025/earnings-fy-2025-q1) already use Microsoft 365 Copilot to offload repetitive tasks like email triage and meeting notes via Teams. But Microsoft didn’t stop there. Microsoft introduced\xa0[new agents in Microsoft 365](https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/blog/microsoft365copilotblog/introducing-new-agents-in-microsoft-365/4296918) to streamline entire business processes, freeing up employees to focus on higher-value work.\\n\\n![Image 7](blob:http://localhost/f19e56331cf34a059197d5fb5b6082dc)\\n\\n[Neudesic’s AI Agent Assist](https://www.neudesic.com/blog/ai-powered-next-gen-agents-accelerating-onboarding-and-boosting-productivity-for-the-heartbeat-of-the-utility-call-center/) is one standout example. By using large language models (LLMs), AI Agent Assist provides call center agents with quick access to information and real-time support, which improves service quality by 40%. As a result, this allows call centers to transform customer service from reactive to proactive, boosting productivity and customer satisfaction.\\n\\nThese enhancements represent a significant leap in collaboration and information management, simplifying workflows and enhancing productivity across organizations.\\n\\n5\\\\. Cybersecurity: A Must-Have Strategy\\n---------------------------------------\\n\\nCybersecurity continued to be a pressing concern in 2024, with AI playing an increasingly pivotal role. According to the [Microsoft’s Digital Defense Report](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/security-insider/intelligence-reports/microsoft-digital-defense-report-2024#section-master-oc537b), AI integration into cyber defense improved threat detection and response. With over 176,000 incidents detected across 5,600 organizations in May alone, the scale of cyber threats underscored the urgency for advanced defenses.\\n\\nAI-powered tools enhanced capabilities like anomaly detection, threat analysis, and remediation, which are critical given the rising frequency and sophistication of attacks. Operational technology systems and AI itself were key targets for attackers, exploiting system vulnerabilities and enabling large-scale social engineering attacks. To combat this, businesses relied on AI to streamline processes like data labeling, policy enhancement, and monitoring generative AI applications to prevent oversharing or leaks.\\n\\nIn 2024, it became clear that AI-driven solutions weren’t just beneficial but were also critical to stay ahead of evolving cyber threats.\\n\\n6\\\\. Ethical and Responsible AI: Rules Get Real\\n----------------------------------------------\\n\\nWith AI becoming more prevalent, the conversation around ethics and regulation intensified in 2024. Governments worldwide introduced new AI regulations aimed at protecting privacy, ensuring accountability, and preventing misuse. In the US, there are more than [120 AI bills](https://www.whitecase.com/insight-our-thinking/ai-watch-global-regulatory-tracker-united-states) under review by the Congress.\\n\\nGovernments worldwide have introduced new laws designed to regulate AI technologies, particularly as it relates to data privacy and ethics. One of the most influential frameworks is the [European Union’s AI Act](https://hyperight.com/panel-european-artificial-intelligence-act-and-how-it-will-impact-data-and-ai-innovation-efforts-across-industries-and-functions/), which establishes clear rules for AI deployment in Europe. These regulations aim to protect users from risks related to AI, such as biased algorithms and data misuse. Companies operating in Europe will now need to ensure their AI tools meet compliance standards.\\n\\n7\\\\. AI at Work: Smarter and Faster Operations\\n---------------------------------------------\\n\\nAI is not only changing how businesses operate, but also redefining entire industries. From supply chain optimization to predictive analytics, AI tools helped companies make smarter and faster decisions.\\n\\n![Image 9](blob:http://localhost/f2865e73526a85a7b49fb80078261209)\\n\\n[Neudesic’s Supply Chain Control Tower](https://www.neudesic.com/blog/supply-chain-control-towers-benefits/) is a prime example. The platform provides organizations real-time visibility to manage and optimize their supply chain performance. This results in a 50% faster resolution time and a 20% cost reduction.\\n\\nIn the utilities sector, [Neudesic’s State of AI in Energy & Utilities Report](https://www.neudesic.com/ebook/state-of-ai-in-utilities/) revealed that AI adoption is driving modernization across utility companies, with 66% of organizations seeing operational improvements. From grid management to energy forecasting, AI-powered analytics are helping utilities become more agile and efficient.\\n\\n![Image 11](blob:http://localhost/44bd0dc0e095a0e9eb5ee79dbf45f0d4)\\n\\n8\\\\. AI in Science: Faster Scientific Discoveries, Better Healthcare\\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\\n\\nLastly, another notable AI trend is the significant advancements in science and medicine,\xa0improving both the efficiency of scientific discoveries and medical diagnostics and treatments.\\n\\nTake the [Da Vinci Surgical System](https://www.intuitive.com/en-us/patients/da-vinci-robotic-surgery/about-the-systems#:~:text=Your%20surgeon%20in%20control,or%20a%20few%20small%20incisions.&text=The%20da%20Vinci%20system%20is,back%20to%20what%20matters%20most.), which uses an AI robot to facilitate minimally invasive surgical procedures. By enhancing precision and control, the system helps surgeons perform complex operations with reduced recovery times for patients.\\n\\nIn medicine, models like [AlphaMissense](https://deepmind.google/discover/blog/a-catalogue-of-genetic-mutations-to-help-pinpoint-the-cause-of-diseases/) have improved genetic mutation classification. This technology increases the accuracy of genetic diagnostics, helping doctors predict the likelihood of diseases linked to genetic mutations. individuals Microsoft helped train and certify over the past year has been updated to 23 million and includes initiatives across Microsoft._\\n\\nIn 2024, generative AI emerged as a key driver for business outcomes across every industry. Already this new generation of AI is **[having an incredible impact](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/aka.ms/AIcustomersBlog___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjI0ZmFhZWY0OGM5YjcwMTU4OWNlY2JmYmNjZTI4MGZjOjY6MjI2YzoyYzY5NTMwNmZmNTM4YmZiYTIzOGE2ZDdhMjU3N2JjYWNhYWMwMDgyZDUwYmIxMjI2YmM1YTUwZjVmNThkNzMwOnA6RjpG)**on our world — yet companies and industries are just scratching the surface of what’s possible as they continue to develop new use cases across every role and function.\\n\\nTo help guide organizations on their AI transformation journey, Microsoft recently commissioned a new study through IDC, [**The Business Opportunity of AI**](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/info.microsoft.com/ww-landing-business-opportunity-of-ai.html___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6YzEzMzo1Y2E2ZTI1ZTgyNzNiMjQ0ZDhjOTJhMmRjNjA1YzRhNWIwNGU4MjcwZmRjNDc0YjBmZjFkNDhmZDg4MDNjM2YwOnA6VDpG). IDC’s findings show that when organizations truly commit to and invest in AI, the return on investment (ROI) potential grows significantly.\\n\\n[![Image 3: A graphic showing the IDC study’s top 3 key findings.](https://blogs.microsoft.com/wp-content/uploads/prod/2024/11/OMB-IDC_Social-Stat-2_1080x1920.jpg)](https://blogs.microsoft.com/wp-content/uploads/prod/2024/11/OMB-IDC_Social-Stat-2_1080x1920.jpg)\\n\\nAccording to IDC, the study’s findings reflect a tipping point as AI gains momentum across industries. As companies worldwide go deeper with AI, Microsoft customers continue to deploy innovative new solutions and discover how tools like [Copilot can transform their day-to-day work](https://news.microsoft.com/source/?post_type=features&p=8580). In telecommunications, [Lumen Technologies](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/news.microsoft.com/source/features/digital-transformation/the-only-way-how-copilot-is-helping-propel-an-evolution-at-lumen-technologies___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6OTdkYzoxYjM0ZDU2ZDhiNjFiNTkyNGRiMzZlZDkzOGE5M2U2NTRiZTgyYzRjYzA4MWJhZGFkNDFlODQ5ZWE0NWFkMGUwOnA6VDpG) estimates Copilot is saving sellers an average of four hours a week, equating to $50 million annually. In healthcare, [Chi Mei Medical Center](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/news.microsoft.com/source/asia/features/taiwan-hospital-deploys-ai-copilots-to-lighten-workloads-for-doctors-nurses-and-pharmacists___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6OGVkMTo5YmJiOGY1MDE3Y2M4ZjIwYWIyNTU5OTgzN2M2ZDJiYzZlZDg4NDM4OGRhYjdhZjQ4MWMyMDVkZmFkZjIxYzljOnA6VDpG) doctors now spend 15 minutes instead of an hour writing medical reports, and nurses can document patient information in under five minutes. Pharmacists are now able to double the number of patients they see per day. In retail, AI models help [Coles](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/news.microsoft.com/source/asia/features/coles-deepens-its-relationship-with-shoppers-using-ai-to-understand-the-customer-experience-and-improve-efficiency-in-store___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6YjM3ODplZDFmODU5OTM4ODRhMTJiYTVjNmFmNDU5N2U0OTBjZGY0ZDExMWVmZTA5YjVmM2U2ZTI1YTNiOTM3YzBlY2Y1OnA6VDpG) predict the flow of 20,000 stock-keeping units to 850 stores with remarkable accuracy, generating 1.6 billion predictions daily.\\n\\n### **IDC’s 2024 top 5 trends for AI**\\n\\nIDC’s findings align with what Microsoft is seeing as we work with companies across industries to deploy AI. We’ve highlighted [more than 200 of our top AI customer stories](https://blogs.microsoft.com/blog/2024/11/12/how-real-world-businesses-are-transforming-with-ai/) to show a sampling of how AI is already driving impact today. Below is a look at the top trends we’re seeing in IDC’s study and the impact of those trends on organizations working with AI today.\\n\\n**#1 Enhanced productivity has become table stakes.** Employee productivity is the No. 1 business outcome that companies are trying to achieve with AI. The study shows that 92% of AI users surveyed are using AI for productivity, and 43% say productivity use cases have provided the greatest ROI. While productivity is a top goal, generative AI use cases that are close behind include customer engagement, topline growth, cost management and product or service innovation — and nearly half of the companies surveyed expect AI to have a high degree of impact across all those areas over the next 24 months.\\n\\n> **Customer snapshot:**\\n> \\n> \\n> _At the global marketing and advertising agency dentsu, employees are already saving 15 to 30 minutes a day using Copilot for tasks such as summarizing chats, generating presentations and building executive summaries._\\n> \\n> \\n> **_“Copilot has transformed the way we deliver creative concepts to our clients, enabling real-time collaboration. Agility, security and uniqueness are crucial, but our goal is to lead this transformation company-wide, from top to bottom.”_**\\n> \\n> \\n> _— Takuya Kodama, Business Strategy Manager at dentsu_\\n\\n**#2 Companies are gravitating to more advanced AI solutions.**In the next 24 months, more companies expect to build custom AI solutions tailored directly to industry needs and business processes, including custom copilots and AI agents. This shows a growing maturity in AI fluency as companies realize the value of out-of-the-box use cases and expand to more advanced scenarios.\\n\\n> **Customer snapshot:**\\n> \\n> \\n> _Siemens has developed the Siemens Industrial Copilot, which has eased the challenges caused by increasing complexity and labor shortages for dozens of customers in different industries._\\n> \\n> \\n> **_“In full appreciation of GenAI’s transformational potential, it’s important to remember that production does not have an ‘undo’ button. It takes diligence and effort to mature AI to industrial-grade quality. The Siemens Industrial Copilot for Engineering significantly eases our customers’ workload and addresses the pressing challenges of skill shortages and increasing complexity in industrial automation. This AI-powered solution is a game-changer for our industry with over 50 customers already using it to boost efficiency and tackle labor shortages.”_**\\n> \\n> \\n> _— Boris Scharinger, AI Strategist at Siemens Digital Industries_\\n\\n**#3 Generative AI adoption and value is growing across industries.** Even though it is relatively new to the market, generative AI adoption is rapidly expanding — 75% of respondents report current usage up from 55% in 2023. The ROI of generative AI is highest in Financial Services, followed by Media & Telco, Mobility, Retail & Consumer Packaged Goods, Energy, Manufacturing, Healthcare and Education. Overall, generative AI is generating higher ROI across industries.\\n\\n> **Customer snapshot:**\\n> \\n> \\n> _Providence has leveraged AI to extend and enhance patient care, streamline processes and workflows and improve the effectiveness of caregivers._\\n> \\n> \\n> _**“Whether we’re partnering with organizations on the leading edge of this technology — like Microsoft — and building bespoke solutions through Azure OpenAI Service, advancing clinical research to help cancer patients receive personalized and precise treatments faster, or ‘hitting the easy button’ and adopting established technologies like Microsoft 365 Copilot or DAX Copilot, we have successfully stayed on the forefront of this tech revolution. For example, physicians who use DAX Copilot save an average of 5.33 minutes per visit, and 80% of physicians have reported lower cognitive burden after using DAX Copilot.”**_\\n> \\n> \\n> _— Sarah Vaezy, EVP, Chief Strategy and Digital Officer at Providence_\\n\\n**#4 AI leaders are seeing greater returns and accelerated innovation.** While companies using generative AI are averaging $3.7x ROI, the top leaders using generative AI are realizing significantly higher returns, with an average ROI of $10.3. In addition to the enhanced business value, leaders are also on an accelerated path to build and implement new solutions — 29% of leaders implement AI in less than 3 months versus 6% of companies in the laggard category.\\n\\n> **Customer snapshot:**\\n> \\n> \\n> _Södra is an international forest industry group that processes forest products from 52,000 owners into renewable, climate-smart products for international market. Every day Södra collects and interprets climate impact data to make thousands of decisions for every part of the value chain._\\n> \\n> \\n> _**“With innovative AI technology from Microsoft, our business experts and data scientists have been able to help make us more sustainable while also improving revenue significantly.”**_\\n> \\n> \\n> _— Cristian Brolin, Chief Digital Officer at Södra_\\n\\n**#5 Looking ahead: Skilling remains a top challenge**. Thirty percent of respondents indicated a lack of specialized AI skills in-house, and 26 percent say they lack employees with the skills needed to learn and work with AI. The rapid evolution of AI has ushered in a new era of digital transformation, with generative AI leading the charge. Investment in this groundbreaking technology is projected by [PWC](https://aimagazine.com/articles/examining-the-big-openai-and-pwc-enterprise-deal) to contribute a staggering US$15.7tn to the global economy in 2030,underscoring its pivotal role in shaping the future of business and society.\\n\\nFrom revolutionising [healthcare](https://aimagazine.com/ai-applications/alphafold-3-google-deepmind-seeks-to-transform-healthcare) with AI-driven diagnostics to transforming [financial services](https://aimagazine.com/articles/ey-finance-leaders-turn-to-ai-to-solve-esg-data-problems) with intelligent algorithms, the impact of AI is far-reaching and profound.\\n\\nHowever, this technological leap forward also brings new challenges, particularly in the realms of ethics, regulation, and data security.\\n\\nIn light of this, AI Magazine presents a comprehensive list of the top 10 AI trends of 2024 to understand the AI developments of this year and gain a glimpse of what could be in store for 2025.\\n\\n10. AI governance and ethics\\n----------------------------\\n\\nAI governance and ethics\\n\\nAI governance and ethics have become paramount concerns as artificial intelligence technologies continue to reshape our world. The UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, adopted by 193 countries in 2021, stands as a cornerstone in this field. This comprehensive framework emphasises four core values: respect for human rights, fostering just societies, environmental well-being, and diversity and inclusiveness. It interprets AI broadly, recognising the rapid pace of technological change and the need for future-proof policies.\\n\\nThe recommendation outlines eleven key areas for policy actions, moving beyond high-level principles to practical strategies. These include sustainability, fairness, technical safety, accountability, explainability, and data stewardship. To support the implementation of these principles, UNESCO has established the Global AI Ethics and Governance Observatory. This platform serves as a vital resource for policymakers, regulators, academics, and civil society, offering country profiles, expert insights, and good practices in AI ethics and governance. The observatory\'s AI Ethics and Governance Lab gathers contributions, research, and toolkits to address pressing challenges in responsible AI innovation, standards, and institutional capacities.\\n\\n9.AI talent demand\\n------------------\\n\\nAI talent demand\\n\\nThe demand for AI talent has skyrocketed in recent years, with job postings incorporating AI skills as a requirement surging by 130% over the last two years. This trend is particularly evident in the field of generative AI, where roles have seen an unprecedented 1,300% increase in demand. The surge reflects the critical importance of AI expertise in today\'s rapidly evolving tech landscape, with machine learning and data science roles growing by 80% and 250%, respectively.\\n\\nThis dramatic shift in the job market has led to a significant skills shortage, with the International Data Corporation predicting that over 90% of companies will face IT skills shortages by 2026. In response, organisations are increasingly looking beyond traditional talent pools, with a 31% increase in demand for specialised skills across borders. This global approach to talent acquisition is reshaping recruitment strategies, as companies seek to build teams with the specialised skills needed to develop and implement AI-driven solutions. The trend towards skills-based hiring is further emphasised by the fact that 80% of companies are now prioritising becoming skills-based organisations, with a particular focus on AI and related technologies.\\n\\n7. Open source AI\\n-----------------\\n\\nOpen Source AI\\n\\nOpen source AI has emerged as a powerful force in the realm of technology, fostering collaboration and innovation on a global scale. This approach to AI development allows researchers, developers and organisations to freely access, modify and distribute AI systems, including datasets, code and model parameters. The transparency inherent in open source AI has led to significant advancements in various fields, from natural language processing to computer vision.\\n\\nOne of the most notable examples of open source AI is OpenCV, the Open Source Computer Vision Library. Launched in 1999 as part of an Intel research project, OpenCV has since become a cornerstone in the computer vision community. Its extensive library of algorithms supports a wide array of applications, including facial recognition, object detection and motion tracking. The longevity and versatility of OpenCV underscore the enduring impact of open source AI initiatives. Another prominent player in the open source AI landscape is OpenNN, a neural network library that excels in predictive analytics. Developed by Artelnics, OpenNN has found applications in customer intelligence and industry-specific analytics, demonstrating the practical value of open source AI in business contexts.\\n\\n7. Agentic AI\\n-------------\\n\\nAgentic AI\\n\\nAgentic AI represents a significant leap forward in artificial intelligence, offering a level of autonomy and decision-making capability that sets it apart from traditional AI systems. This advanced form of AI is designed to operate independently, making decisions and adapting to changing environments with minimal human intervention. Unlike its predecessors, agentic AI can analyse complex situations, formulate strategies and execute multi-step tasks to achieve predefined goals. At its core, agentic AI employs sophisticated algorithms that enable it to understand and interpret natural language instructions, develop action plans and adjust its approach based on real-time feedback.\\n\\nThis adaptability allows it to optimise workflows, enhance customer service experiences and streamline operations across various industries. For instance, in financial services, agentic AI excels at fraud detection by analysing vast amounts of data and autonomously initiating resolution workflows when issues are identified. Its ability to learn from interactions and improve over time positions agentic AI as a powerful tool for enterprises seeking to boost efficiency and maintain a competitive edge in an increasingly dynamic marketplace.\\n\\n6.AI in scientific research\\n---------------------------\\n\\nAI in scientific research\\n\\nAI is rapidly transforming scientific research across numerous disciplines, offering unprecedented capabilities in data analysis, hypothesis generation, and experimental design. In genomics, AI algorithms can swiftly analyse genetic sequences to identify disease markers, whilst in drug discovery, machine learning models predict the efficacy of new compounds with remarkable accuracy. These advancements have led to significant time and cost reductions in research processes, with genomics seeing a 60% acceleration in research and a 50% reduction in costs.\\n\\nThe integration of AI in scientific research extends beyond data analysis. Natural Language Processing (NLP) systems are revolutionising how researchers manage the ever-growing volume of scientific literature. These AI-powered tools can summarise vast collections of research papers, extracting key findings and methodologies, thus enabling scientists to stay abreast of developments in their field without the need to read through entire papers. Moreover, AI is fostering interdisciplinary research by integrating data and methodologies from different scientific fields, leading to innovative solutions for complex problems such as climate change and its socioeconomic impacts.\\n\\n5.Customisable AI\\n-----------------\\n\\nCustomisable AI\\n\\nCustomisable AI models have emerged as a powerful tool for businesses seeking to harness the full potential of AI. Unlike generic solutions, these bespoke models are tailored to address specific challenges and optimise performance in targeted areas. By aligning closely with a company\'s unique data sets and objectives, customised AI models deliver more accurate insights and enhanced operational efficiency.\\n\\nThe shift towards customised AI solutions is driven by the recognition that off-the-shelf tools often fall short of meeting the nuanced needs of each organisation. These tailored models can be fine-tuned for specific tasks, seamlessly integrated with existing systems, and designed to process unique data sets that reflect the intricacies of each business. For instance, a retail company might leverage a custom AI model to analyse consumer behaviour and optimise inventory management, whilst a healthcare provider could develop a bespoke solution to predict patient outcomes and refine treatment plans.This level of personalisation not only ensures higher accuracy but also provides a significant competitive advantage in today\'s data-driven landscape.\\n\\n4. Small Language Models\\n------------------------\\n\\nSmall Language Models\\n\\nSmall Language Models (SLMs) have emerged as a formidable force in the realm of AI, offering a compelling alternative to their larger counterparts. These compact AI models, with parameter counts ranging from a few million to a few billion, are designed to process, understand and generate natural language content with remarkable efficiency. SLMs employ advanced techniques such as model compression, knowledge distillation and transfer learning to condense the broad capabilities of larger models into a more focused, domain-specific toolset.\\n\\nOne of the key advantages of SLMs is their ability to operate in resource-constrained environments, making them ideal for edge devices and mobile applications. For instance, Granite 3.0 1B-A400M and Granite 3.0 3B-A800M boast total parameter counts of 1 billion and 3 billion respectively, yet their active parameter counts at inference are a mere 400 million and 800 million.\\n\\nThis reduction in parameters translates to decreased processing times and lower latency, allowing SLMs to respond swiftly to user queries. Moreover, their compact nature makes them more environmentally sustainable and cost-effective, as they consume less energy and require fewer computational resources compared to their larger counterparts.\\n\\n3.AI for workplace productivity\\n-------------------------------\\n\\nAI for workplace productivity\\n\\nAI is revolutionising workplace productivity, offering a plethora of tools designed to streamline tasks and enhance efficiency across various sectors. From automating mundane administrative duties to providing sophisticated data analysis, AI-powered solutions are transforming how businesses operate in the digital age.\\n\\nOne notable example is Notion AI, an intelligent feature integrated into the popular workspace platform. This innovative tool assists users in generating content, answering queries and autofilling tables within their Notion pages. By leveraging AI capabilities, Notion enables teams to brainstorm more effectively, draft documents with greater speed and manage projects with increased precision.\\n\\nSimilarly, Otter.ai has emerged as a game-changer in the realm of meeting productivity. This AI-powered assistant offers real-time transcription, speaker identification and audio-text synchronisation, allowing professionals to focus on discussions rather than note-taking. These advancements not only save time but also enhance the quality of work output, demonstrating the tangible benefits of AI in boosting workplace efficiency.\\n\\n2. Gen AI democratisation\\n-------------------------\\n\\nGen AI\\n\\nGen AI has emerged as a powerful force in democratising innovation, placing sophisticated tools in the hands of individuals across various sectors. This technological leap forward has significantly lowered the barriers to entry for creative and analytical endeavours, enabling a broader range of users to harness AI\'s capabilities without extensive technical expertise.\\n\\nThe impact of this democratisation is particularly evident in the business world, where Gartner predicts that by 2026, more than 80% of enterprises will be using Gen AI APIs and models in production environments, a stark increase from less than 5% in 2023.\\n\\nThis shift signifies a move towards more inclusive and efficient business practices, with AI tools being integrated into everyday applications. For instance, sales teams can now utilise AI-powered chatbots and proposal generators to streamline their operations, enhancing productivity without the need for extensive data science teams.\\n\\nHowever, this widespread adoption is not without its challenges. A Boston Consulting Group study revealed that over half of executives surveyed are actively discouraging the use of generative AI due to a lack of understanding, whilst 37% are in a state of experimentation without proper policies or controls in place.\\n\\n1. Multimodal AI\\n----------------\\n\\n![Image 4: Youtube Placeholder](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/fD9SiYSpiwE/hqdefault.jpg)\\n\\nMultimodal AI represents a significant leap forward in AI, combining various data types such as text, images, audio, and video to create a more comprehensive understanding of the world. Unlike traditional unimodal systems that rely on a single data type, multimodal AI integrates diverse inputs, enabling it to perform complex tasks with greater accuracy and contextual awareness.\\n\\nAt its core, multimodal AI comprises three key components: the input module, fusion module, and output module. The input module consists of multiple unimodal neural networks, each handling a different data type. The fusion module then processes and aligns the information from each modality, employing techniques such as early fusion to concatenate raw data. Companies Race to Develop AI Search\\n\\nAI tools that use\xa0[large language models (LLMs)](https://www.techopedia.com/definition/34948/large-language-model-llm) have the potential to change how people find information online.\\n\\n(And potentially disrupt Google\'s [dominance of the search market](https://www.statista.com/statistics/216573/worldwide-market-share-of-search-engines/)).\\n\\n***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/z13rawVHSN2psVJk9ITL)  \\nInterest in “AI search” has grown significantly in 2024.***\\n\\n![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/z13rawVHSN2psVJk9ITL)\\n\\nThe underlying LLMs behind an interface like ChatGPT work by first analyzing large amounts of information and “learning” it. predict a sequence of human language that will answer the question.\\n\\n**Instead of producing a list of relevant websites, the tool gives written answers pulled from a combination of different sources.**\\n\\nAnd, these platforms go way beyond simple queries like finding the capital of Brazil or the current temperature.\\n\\nUsers can query broad questions like how to plan a dinner party Natural Language Processing Drives New Use Cases for AI\\n\\nFew things in the AI industry have more promising business use cases than natural language processing (NLP).\\n\\n***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/152CfchRaOBZmnbBzK0F)  \\nSearch volume for “natural language processing” is growing.***\\n\\n![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/152CfchRaOBZmnbBzK0F)\\n\\nOur world is wrapped in text. Analyzing, formatting, translating, and using texts is essential to all types of business around the world.\\n\\nAnd it’s not just words. NLP is being used to [analyze data](https://www.linguamatics.com/what-text-mining-text-analytics-and-natural-language-processing) in ways that are far different from prior statistical methods we’ve used.\\n\\n***![nlp-tool-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/TAU5frk4SVquQhZAs5O7)  \\nWith an NLP tool, organizations can process data up to 10x faster and analyze unstructured data via human language.***\\n\\n![nlp-tool-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/TAU5frk4SVquQhZAs5O7)\\n\\nSo, what is NLP?\\n\\nIt\'s basically a way for [computers to speak human language](https://www.techtarget.com/searchenterpriseai/definition/natural-language-processing-NLP).\\n\\nIn the past, computers were only able to understand human language if it was first translated into code. world](https://explodingtopics.com/blog/data-generated-per-day) could hit [612 zettabytes](https://www.statista.com/chart/17727/global-data-creation-forecasts/) by 2030 and 2,142 zettabytes by 2024 is coming to an end, and this year has been nothing short of revolutionary for AI. AI didn’t just evolve— It redefined what’s possible, shaping industries with advancements that stretched across customer service, cybersecurity, and even medical research.  AI adoption is accelerating rapidly as companies look for new ways to increase efficiencies further and drive innovation.

Reflecting on another pivotal year for AI, here’s a look into the 8 biggest AI trends that made headlines in 2024.

1\. Generative AI: From Hype to Essential Business Tool
-------------------------------------------------------

![Image 4](https://www.neudesic.com/wp-content/uploads/in-blog-2024-AI-recap_AI-usage-increase-1024x398.png)

In just one year, from 2023 to 2024, generative AI dramatically shifted from a phase of rapid experimentation to a period of essential integrations into business operations. Furthermore, [IDC’s global survey](https://blogs.microsoft.com/blog/2024/11/12/idcs-2024-ai-opportunity-study-top-five-ai-trends-to-watch/) of enterprise organizations found that generative AI adoption is rapidly expanding with usage figures jumping from 55% in 2023 to 75%. Across industries, businesses began to embed AI into their core operations —particularly generative AI, which has rapidly taken hold in marketing and sales functions, where text-based communications and personalization serve as key drivers.  Companies in financial services, retail, and media have used generative AI to personalize customer experiences, reduce time-to-market, and streamline operations. In short, generative AI has transitioned from hype and proof-of-concept experiments to broader adoption, with companies emphasizing real-world implementations with tangible results.

![Image 5](blob:http://localhost/ad49616dad180b71b08861433333c330)

OpenAI’s ChatGPT played a key role in this surge. By December 2024, [ChatGPT reached 300 million weekly active users](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/12/04/openais-active-user-count-soars-to-300-million-people-per-week.html)—up from 200 million just four months prior. This explosive growth is a sign that generative AI is no longer a futuristic concept but an essential, versatile tool—one that’s quickly becoming more ingrained with our culture and society both professionally and personally—and it’s here to stay.

2\. Multimodal AI: Diverse Content from One Model
-------------------------------------------------

Another significant AI trend was the major advancements in multimodal AI—systems that understand and generate text, images, and audio from a single interface. Multimodal AI reduces the need for multiple specialized tools, making it easier for organizations to create and manage diverse content. Fun fact: the cover image of this blog was created using multimodal AI, courtesy of [Midjourney](https://www.midjourney.com/home).

Two major players, [OpenAI’s Sora](https://openai.com/index/learning-to-reason-with-llms/) and [Google’s Veo](https://deepmind.google/technologies/veo/veo-1/), captured the AI spotlight by providing impressive text-to-video capabilities. These tools promise to simplify content production for marketing, media, and education, allowing users to generate video content directly from a written prompt. The result? Faster production cycles and reduced creative bottlenecks.

3\. Reasoning AI: Solving Complex Problems
------------------------------------------

One of the most game-changing AI trends this year was the focus on building robust reasoning capabilities into AI systems. From new prompting methods to new model training techniques to new AI agent architectures, there have been many different approaches to building AI systems capable of solving increasingly complex tasks by iteratively planning, solving, and evaluating their work.

Models with advanced reasoning capabilities, like  [OpenAI’s o1](https://openai.com/index/introducing-openai-o1-preview/), can already solve complex problems using logical steps that are similar to how humans think before responding to difficult questions. These capabilities will continue to be useful in fields like science, coding, math, law and medicine, allowing models to compare contracts, generate code and execute multistep workflows.

Microsoft’s [Phi models](https://news.microsoft.com/source/features/ai/the-phi-3-small-language-models-with-big-potential/) demonstrated how smaller models, when trained on high-quality data, can improve model performance and reasoning. Meanwhile, Orca and [Orca 2](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/blog/orca-2-teaching-small-language-models-how-to-reason/?msockid=1dbcd2bacdc96a0e1328c686cc736b2f) showed how synthetic data for post-training could improve model performance, making small models as capable as much larger language models. These training techniques help smaller models perform better on specialized tasks. Making models faster, better and more specialized will help create new and more useful AI experiences.

4\. AI Agents: From Reactive to Proactive
-----------------------------------------

AI agents are swiftly evolving and transcending across differing business types and industries. [AI Agents extend the ability of LLMs](https://www.neudesic.com/blog/ai-agent-systems/) by equipping the model with tools and enabling it to act on a user’s behalf. Nearly [70% of Fortune 500 companies](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/investor/events/fy-2025/earnings-fy-2025-q1) already use Microsoft 365 Copilot to offload repetitive tasks like email triage and meeting notes via Teams. But Microsoft didn’t stop there. Microsoft introduced [new agents in Microsoft 365](https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/blog/microsoft365copilotblog/introducing-new-agents-in-microsoft-365/4296918) to streamline entire business processes, freeing up employees to focus on higher-value work.

![Image 7](blob:http://localhost/f19e56331cf34a059197d5fb5b6082dc)

[Neudesic’s AI Agent Assist](https://www.neudesic.com/blog/ai-powered-next-gen-agents-accelerating-onboarding-and-boosting-productivity-for-the-heartbeat-of-the-utility-call-center/) is one standout example. By using large language models (LLMs), AI Agent Assist provides call center agents with quick access to information and real-time support, which improves service quality by 40%. As a result, this allows call centers to transform customer service from reactive to proactive, boosting productivity and customer satisfaction.

These enhancements represent a significant leap in collaboration and information management, simplifying workflows and enhancing productivity across organizations.

5\. Cybersecurity: A Must-Have Strategy
---------------------------------------

Cybersecurity continued to be a pressing concern in 2024, with AI playing an increasingly pivotal role. According to the [Microsoft’s Digital Defense Report](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/security-insider/intelligence-reports/microsoft-digital-defense-report-2024#section-master-oc537b), AI integration into cyber defense improved threat detection and response. With over 176,000 incidents detected across 5,600 organizations in May alone, the scale of cyber threats underscored the urgency for advanced defenses.

AI-powered tools enhanced capabilities like anomaly detection, threat analysis, and remediation, which are critical given the rising frequency and sophistication of attacks. Operational technology systems and AI itself were key targets for attackers, exploiting system vulnerabilities and enabling large-scale social engineering attacks. To combat this, businesses relied on AI to streamline processes like data labeling, policy enhancement, and monitoring generative AI applications to prevent oversharing or leaks.

In 2024, it became clear that AI-driven solutions weren’t just beneficial but were also critical to stay ahead of evolving cyber threats.

6\. Ethical and Responsible AI: Rules Get Real
----------------------------------------------

With AI becoming more prevalent, the conversation around ethics and regulation intensified in 2024. Governments worldwide introduced new AI regulations aimed at protecting privacy, ensuring accountability, and preventing misuse. In the US, there are more than [120 AI bills](https://www.whitecase.com/insight-our-thinking/ai-watch-global-regulatory-tracker-united-states) under review by the Congress.

Governments worldwide have introduced new laws designed to regulate AI technologies, particularly as it relates to data privacy and ethics. One of the most influential frameworks is the [European Union’s AI Act](https://hyperight.com/panel-european-artificial-intelligence-act-and-how-it-will-impact-data-and-ai-innovation-efforts-across-industries-and-functions/), which establishes clear rules for AI deployment in Europe. These regulations aim to protect users from risks related to AI, such as biased algorithms and data misuse. Companies operating in Europe will now need to ensure their AI tools meet compliance standards.

7\. AI at Work: Smarter and Faster Operations
---------------------------------------------

AI is not only changing how businesses operate, but also redefining entire industries. From supply chain optimization to predictive analytics, AI tools helped companies make smarter and faster decisions.

![Image 9](blob:http://localhost/f2865e73526a85a7b49fb80078261209)

[Neudesic’s Supply Chain Control Tower](https://www.neudesic.com/blog/supply-chain-control-towers-benefits/) is a prime example. The platform provides organizations real-time visibility to manage and optimize their supply chain performance. This results in a 50% faster resolution time and a 20% cost reduction.

In the utilities sector, [Neudesic’s State of AI in Energy & Utilities Report](https://www.neudesic.com/ebook/state-of-ai-in-utilities/) revealed that AI adoption is driving modernization across utility companies, with 66% of organizations seeing operational improvements. From grid management to energy forecasting, AI-powered analytics are helping utilities become more agile and efficient.

![Image 11](blob:http://localhost/44bd0dc0e095a0e9eb5ee79dbf45f0d4)

8\. AI in Science: Faster Scientific Discoveries, Better Healthcare
-------------------------------------------------------------------

Lastly, another notable AI trend is the significant advancements in science and medicine, improving both the efficiency of scientific discoveries and medical diagnostics and treatments.

Take the [Da Vinci Surgical System](https://www.intuitive.com/en-us/patients/da-vinci-robotic-surgery/about-the-systems#:~:text=Your%20surgeon%20in%20control,or%20a%20few%20small%20incisions.&text=The%20da%20Vinci%20system%20is,back%20to%20what%20matters%20most.), which uses an AI robot to facilitate minimally invasive surgical procedures. By enhancing precision and control, the system helps surgeons perform complex operations with reduced recovery times for patients.

In medicine, models like [AlphaMissense](https://deepmind.google/discover/blog/a-catalogue-of-genetic-mutations-to-help-pinpoint-the-cause-of-diseases/) have improved genetic mutation classification. This technology increases the accuracy of genetic diagnostics, helping doctors predict the likelihood of diseases linked to genetic mutations. Such advancements are paving the way for more personalized medicine and earlier disease detection.

Looking Ahead to 2025
---------------------

The 2024 AI trends showed us that AI isn’t just an experiment— it’s becoming an integral part of our business operations and in our society. Generative AI is now a daily tool, multimodal AI simplifies content creation, and reasoning AI solves real-world problems. With AI agents optimizing workflows and ethical AI guiding regulatory compliance, the future of AI feels more collaborative and grounded in responsibility.

As businesses continue to adopt AI for competitive advantage, one thing is clear: 2025 is likely to bring even more sophisticated AI capabilities that are easier to use and harder to ignore.

In 2024, generative AI emerged as a key driver for business outcomes across every industry. Already this new generation of AI is **[having an incredible impact](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/aka.ms/AIcustomersBlog___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjI0ZmFhZWY0OGM5YjcwMTU4OWNlY2JmYmNjZTI4MGZjOjY6MjI2YzoyYzY5NTMwNmZmNTM4YmZiYTIzOGE2ZDdhMjU3N2JjYWNhYWMwMDgyZDUwYmIxMjI2YmM1YTUwZjVmNThkNzMwOnA6RjpG)**on our world — yet companies and industries are just scratching the surface of what’s possible as they continue to develop new use cases across every role and function.

To help guide organizations on their AI transformation journey, Microsoft recently commissioned a new study through IDC, [**The Business Opportunity of AI**](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/info.microsoft.com/ww-landing-business-opportunity-of-ai.html___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6YzEzMzo1Y2E2ZTI1ZTgyNzNiMjQ0ZDhjOTJhMmRjNjA1YzRhNWIwNGU4MjcwZmRjNDc0YjBmZjFkNDhmZDg4MDNjM2YwOnA6VDpG). IDC’s findings show that when organizations truly commit to and invest in AI, the return on investment (ROI) potential grows significantly.

[![Image 3: A graphic showing the IDC study’s top 3 key findings.](https://blogs.microsoft.com/wp-content/uploads/prod/2024/11/OMB-IDC_Social-Stat-2_1080x1920.jpg)](https://blogs.microsoft.com/wp-content/uploads/prod/2024/11/OMB-IDC_Social-Stat-2_1080x1920.jpg)

According to IDC, the study’s findings reflect a tipping point as AI gains momentum across industries. As companies worldwide go deeper with AI, Microsoft customers continue to deploy innovative new solutions and discover how tools like [Copilot can transform their day-to-day work](https://news.microsoft.com/source/?post_type=features&p=8580). In telecommunications, [Lumen Technologies](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/news.microsoft.com/source/features/digital-transformation/the-only-way-how-copilot-is-helping-propel-an-evolution-at-lumen-technologies___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6OTdkYzoxYjM0ZDU2ZDhiNjFiNTkyNGRiMzZlZDkzOGE5M2U2NTRiZTgyYzRjYzA4MWJhZGFkNDFlODQ5ZWE0NWFkMGUwOnA6VDpG) estimates Copilot is saving sellers an average of four hours a week, equating to $50 million annually. In healthcare, [Chi Mei Medical Center](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/news.microsoft.com/source/asia/features/taiwan-hospital-deploys-ai-copilots-to-lighten-workloads-for-doctors-nurses-and-pharmacists___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6OGVkMTo5YmJiOGY1MDE3Y2M4ZjIwYWIyNTU5OTgzN2M2ZDJiYzZlZDg4NDM4OGRhYjdhZjQ4MWMyMDVkZmFkZjIxYzljOnA6VDpG) doctors now spend 15 minutes instead of an hour writing medical reports, and nurses can document patient information in under five minutes. Pharmacists are now able to double the number of patients they see per day. In retail, AI models help [Coles](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/news.microsoft.com/source/asia/features/coles-deepens-its-relationship-with-shoppers-using-ai-to-understand-the-customer-experience-and-improve-efficiency-in-store___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6YjM3ODplZDFmODU5OTM4ODRhMTJiYTVjNmFmNDU5N2U0OTBjZGY0ZDExMWVmZTA5YjVmM2U2ZTI1YTNiOTM3YzBlY2Y1OnA6VDpG) predict the flow of 20,000 stock-keeping units to 850 stores with remarkable accuracy, generating 1.6 billion predictions daily.

### **IDC’s 2024 top 5 trends for AI**

IDC’s findings align with what Microsoft is seeing as we work with companies across industries to deploy AI. We’ve highlighted [more than 200 of our top AI customer stories](https://blogs.microsoft.com/blog/2024/11/12/how-real-world-businesses-are-transforming-with-ai/) to show a sampling of how AI is already driving impact today. Below is a look at the top trends we’re seeing in IDC’s study and the impact of those trends on organizations working with AI today.

**#1 Enhanced productivity has become table stakes.** Employee productivity is the No. 1 business outcome that companies are trying to achieve with AI. The study shows that 92% of AI users surveyed are using AI for productivity, and 43% say productivity use cases have provided the greatest ROI. While productivity is a top goal, generative AI use cases that are close behind include customer engagement, topline growth, cost management and product or service innovation — and nearly half of the companies surveyed expect AI to have a high degree of impact across all those areas over the next 24 months.

> **Customer snapshot:**
> 
> 
> _At the global marketing and advertising agency dentsu, employees are already saving 15 to 30 minutes a day using Copilot for tasks such as summarizing chats, generating presentations and building executive summaries._
> 
> 
> **_“Copilot has transformed the way we deliver creative concepts to our clients, enabling real-time collaboration. Agility, security and uniqueness are crucial, but our goal is to lead this transformation company-wide, from top to bottom.”_**
> 
> 
> _— Takuya Kodama, Business Strategy Manager at dentsu_

**#2 Companies are gravitating to more advanced AI solutions.**In the next 24 months, more companies expect to build custom AI solutions tailored directly to industry needs and business processes, including custom copilots and AI agents. This shows a growing maturity in AI fluency as companies realize the value of out-of-the-box use cases and expand to more advanced scenarios.

> **Customer snapshot:**
> 
> 
> _Siemens has developed the Siemens Industrial Copilot, which has eased the challenges caused by increasing complexity and labor shortages for dozens of customers in different industries._
> 
> 
> **_“In full appreciation of GenAI’s transformational potential, it’s important to remember that production does not have an ‘undo’ button. It takes diligence and effort to mature AI to industrial-grade quality. The Siemens Industrial Copilot for Engineering significantly eases our customers’ workload and addresses the pressing challenges of skill shortages and increasing complexity in industrial automation. This AI-powered solution is a game-changer for our industry with over 50 customers already using it to boost efficiency and tackle labor shortages.”_**
> 
> 
> _— Boris Scharinger, AI Strategist at Siemens Digital Industries_

**#3 Generative AI adoption and value is growing across industries.** Even though it is relatively new to the market, generative AI adoption is rapidly expanding — 75% of respondents report current usage up from 55% in 2023. The ROI of generative AI is highest in Financial Services, followed by Media & Telco, Mobility, Retail & Consumer Packaged Goods, Energy, Manufacturing, Healthcare and Education. Overall, generative AI is generating higher ROI across industries.

> **Customer snapshot:**
> 
> 
> _Providence has leveraged AI to extend and enhance patient care, streamline processes and workflows and improve the effectiveness of caregivers._
> 
> 
> _**“Whether we’re partnering with organizations on the leading edge of this technology — like Microsoft — and building bespoke solutions through Azure OpenAI Service, advancing clinical research to help cancer patients receive personalized and precise treatments faster, or ‘hitting the easy button’ and adopting established technologies like Microsoft 365 Copilot or DAX Copilot, we have successfully stayed on the forefront of this tech revolution. For example, physicians who use DAX Copilot save an average of 5.33 minutes per visit, and 80% of physicians have reported lower cognitive burden after using DAX Copilot.”**_
> 
> 
> _— Sarah Vaezy, EVP, Chief Strategy and Digital Officer at Providence_

**#4 AI leaders are seeing greater returns and accelerated innovation.** While companies using generative AI are averaging $3.7x ROI, the top leaders using generative AI are realizing significantly higher returns, with an average ROI of $10.3. In addition to the enhanced business value, leaders are also on an accelerated path to build and implement new solutions — 29% of leaders implement AI in less than 3 months versus 6% of companies in the laggard category.

> **Customer snapshot:**
> 
> 
> _Södra is an international forest industry group that processes forest products from 52,000 owners into renewable, climate-smart products for international market. Every day Södra collects and interprets climate impact data to make thousands of decisions for every part of the value chain._
> 
> 
> _**“With innovative AI technology from Microsoft, our business experts and data scientists have been able to help make us more sustainable while also improving revenue significantly.”**_
> 
> 
> _— Cristian Brolin, Chief Digital Officer at Södra_

**#5 Looking ahead: Skilling remains a top challenge**. Thirty percent of respondents indicated a lack of specialized AI skills in-house, and 26 percent say they lack employees with the skills needed to learn and work with AI. This dovetails with findings from the **[Microsoft and LinkedIn 2024 Work Trend Index Annual Report](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/www.microsoft.com/en-us/worklab/work-trend-index/ai-at-work-is-here-now-comes-the-hard-part___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6OTVmMzpmYWVjMDJkZmE4ODNlNDYwNDZlN2UzY2ZlNDY3NDQ3YjJjNTIxODgwYTk1YTljNjQ4ZDE0YTgzNDE1MzRkMjlhOnA6VDpG)**, which found that 55 percent of business leaders are concerned about having enough skilled talent to fill roles.

That is why over the past year we have helped train and certify over 23 million people in more than 200 countries in digital skills. And we are committed to working in partnership with governments, educational institutions, industry and civil society to help millions more learn to use AI.

Our focus on generative AI not only drives operational efficiency but also empowers our community to unlock new levels of creativity and impact, further positioning USF as a leader in AI adoption, which includes being among the first universities in the nation to form a college dedicated to AI, cybersecurity and computing.”**_

### [![Image 4: A graphic showing key data from the IDC study. ](https://blogs.microsoft.com/wp-content/uploads/prod/2024/11/NEW-IDC_Social-Stat-10x-_1920x1080_Final-Final_11_11_24.png)](https://blogs.microsoft.com/wp-content/uploads/prod/2024/11/NEW-IDC_Social-Stat-10x-_1920x1080_Final-Final_11_11_24.png)

### **AI’s growing economic impact**

While companies today are largely implementing out-of-the-box generative AI solutions and seeing significant ROI, more than half of those surveyed expect to build custom industry and line-of-business applications in the next 24 months — demonstrating that today’s ROI is quickly becoming tomorrow’s competitive edge.

“We are at an inflection point of autonomous agent development and are beginning an evolution from using just off-the-shelf assistants and copilots that support knowledge discovery and content generation to custom AI agents to execute complex, multistep workflows across a digital world,” says Ritu Jyoti, GVP/GM, AI and Data Research at IDC. “With responsible technology usage and workplace transformation, IDC predicts that business spending to adopt AI will have a cumulative global economic impact of $19.9 trillion through 2030 and drive 3.5% of global GDP in 2030.”

Key findings from [IDC’s The Business Opportunity](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/info.microsoft.com/ww-landing-business-opportunity-of-ai.html___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6YzEzMzo1Y2E2ZTI1ZTgyNzNiMjQ0ZDhjOTJhMmRjNjA1YzRhNWIwNGU4MjcwZmRjNDc0YjBmZjFkNDhmZDg4MDNjM2YwOnA6VDpG) of AI study include:

*   Generative AI usage jumped from 55% in 2023 to 75% in 2024.
*   For every $1 a company invests in generative AI, the ROI is $3.7x.
*   The top leaders using generative AI are realizing an ROI of $10.3.
*   On average, AI deployments are taking less than 8 months and organizations are realizing value within 13 months.
*   Within 24 months, most organizations plan to expand beyond pre-built AI solutions to advanced AI workloads that are customized or custom-built.
*   The ROI of generative AI is highest in Financial Services, followed by Media & Telco, Mobility, Retail & Consumer Packaged Goods, Energy, Manufacturing, Healthcare and Education.
*   43% say productivity use cases have provided the greatest ROI.
*   The primary way that organizations are monetizing AI today is through productivity use cases. In the next 24 months, a greater focus will be placed on functional and industry use cases.
*   The top barrier when implementing AI is the lack of both technical and day-to-day AI skills.

### **Learn how to fuel your AI journey**

IDC’s study, which included more than 4,000 business leaders and AI decision-makers around the world, also identifies the top barriers organizations face when implementing AI. As businesses integrate new solutions, they navigate important considerations such as data privacy, responsible use and the need for investment in both technology and skills.

Top 10 AI Trends of 2024
========================

By[Kristian McCann](https://aimagazine.com/author/kristian-mccann)

December 11, 2024

AI Magazine highlights the Top 10 trends of 2024

AI Magazine examines the top 10 AI trends of 2024 to understand the developments of this year and see what could be on the agenda for 2025

As we enter 2025, AI continues to reshape industries and redefine the boundaries of technological innovation. The rapid evolution of AI has ushered in a new era of digital transformation, with generative AI leading the charge. Investment in this groundbreaking technology is projected by [PWC](https://aimagazine.com/articles/examining-the-big-openai-and-pwc-enterprise-deal) to contribute a staggering US$15.7tn to the global economy in 2030,underscoring its pivotal role in shaping the future of business and society.

From revolutionising [healthcare](https://aimagazine.com/ai-applications/alphafold-3-google-deepmind-seeks-to-transform-healthcare) with AI-driven diagnostics to transforming [financial services](https://aimagazine.com/articles/ey-finance-leaders-turn-to-ai-to-solve-esg-data-problems) with intelligent algorithms, the impact of AI is far-reaching and profound.

However, this technological leap forward also brings new challenges, particularly in the realms of ethics, regulation, and data security.

In light of this, AI Magazine presents a comprehensive list of the top 10 AI trends of 2024 to understand the AI developments of this year and gain a glimpse of what could be in store for 2025.

10. AI governance and ethics
----------------------------

AI governance and ethics

AI governance and ethics have become paramount concerns as artificial intelligence technologies continue to reshape our world. The UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, adopted by 193 countries in 2021, stands as a cornerstone in this field. This comprehensive framework emphasises four core values: respect for human rights, fostering just societies, environmental well-being, and diversity and inclusiveness. It interprets AI broadly, recognising the rapid pace of technological change and the need for future-proof policies.

The recommendation outlines eleven key areas for policy actions, moving beyond high-level principles to practical strategies. These include sustainability, fairness, technical safety, accountability, explainability, and data stewardship. To support the implementation of these principles, UNESCO has established the Global AI Ethics and Governance Observatory. This platform serves as a vital resource for policymakers, regulators, academics, and civil society, offering country profiles, expert insights, and good practices in AI ethics and governance. The observatory's AI Ethics and Governance Lab gathers contributions, research, and toolkits to address pressing challenges in responsible AI innovation, standards, and institutional capacities.

9.AI talent demand
------------------

AI talent demand

The demand for AI talent has skyrocketed in recent years, with job postings incorporating AI skills as a requirement surging by 130% over the last two years. This trend is particularly evident in the field of generative AI, where roles have seen an unprecedented 1,300% increase in demand. The surge reflects the critical importance of AI expertise in today's rapidly evolving tech landscape, with machine learning and data science roles growing by 80% and 250%, respectively.

This dramatic shift in the job market has led to a significant skills shortage, with the International Data Corporation predicting that over 90% of companies will face IT skills shortages by 2026. In response, organisations are increasingly looking beyond traditional talent pools, with a 31% increase in demand for specialised skills across borders. This global approach to talent acquisition is reshaping recruitment strategies, as companies seek to build teams with the specialised skills needed to develop and implement AI-driven solutions. The trend towards skills-based hiring is further emphasised by the fact that 80% of companies are now prioritising becoming skills-based organisations, with a particular focus on AI and related technologies.

7. Open source AI
-----------------

Open Source AI

Open source AI has emerged as a powerful force in the realm of technology, fostering collaboration and innovation on a global scale. This approach to AI development allows researchers, developers and organisations to freely access, modify and distribute AI systems, including datasets, code and model parameters. The transparency inherent in open source AI has led to significant advancements in various fields, from natural language processing to computer vision.

One of the most notable examples of open source AI is OpenCV, the Open Source Computer Vision Library. Launched in 1999 as part of an Intel research project, OpenCV has since become a cornerstone in the computer vision community. Its extensive library of algorithms supports a wide array of applications, including facial recognition, object detection and motion tracking. The longevity and versatility of OpenCV underscore the enduring impact of open source AI initiatives. Another prominent player in the open source AI landscape is OpenNN, a neural network library that excels in predictive analytics. Developed by Artelnics, OpenNN has found applications in customer intelligence and industry-specific analytics, demonstrating the practical value of open source AI in business contexts.

7. Agentic AI
-------------

Agentic AI

Agentic AI represents a significant leap forward in artificial intelligence, offering a level of autonomy and decision-making capability that sets it apart from traditional AI systems. This advanced form of AI is designed to operate independently, making decisions and adapting to changing environments with minimal human intervention. Unlike its predecessors, agentic AI can analyse complex situations, formulate strategies and execute multi-step tasks to achieve predefined goals. At its core, agentic AI employs sophisticated algorithms that enable it to understand and interpret natural language instructions, develop action plans and adjust its approach based on real-time feedback.

This adaptability allows it to optimise workflows, enhance customer service experiences and streamline operations across various industries. For instance, in financial services, agentic AI excels at fraud detection by analysing vast amounts of data and autonomously initiating resolution workflows when issues are identified. Its ability to learn from interactions and improve over time positions agentic AI as a powerful tool for enterprises seeking to boost efficiency and maintain a competitive edge in an increasingly dynamic marketplace.

6.AI in scientific research
---------------------------

AI in scientific research

AI is rapidly transforming scientific research across numerous disciplines, offering unprecedented capabilities in data analysis, hypothesis generation, and experimental design. In genomics, AI algorithms can swiftly analyse genetic sequences to identify disease markers, whilst in drug discovery, machine learning models predict the efficacy of new compounds with remarkable accuracy. These advancements have led to significant time and cost reductions in research processes, with genomics seeing a 60% acceleration in research and a 50% reduction in costs.

The integration of AI in scientific research extends beyond data analysis. Natural Language Processing (NLP) systems are revolutionising how researchers manage the ever-growing volume of scientific literature. These AI-powered tools can summarise vast collections of research papers, extracting key findings and methodologies, thus enabling scientists to stay abreast of developments in their field without the need to read through entire papers. Moreover, AI is fostering interdisciplinary research by integrating data and methodologies from different scientific fields, leading to innovative solutions for complex problems such as climate change and its socioeconomic impacts.

5.Customisable AI
-----------------

Customisable AI

Customisable AI models have emerged as a powerful tool for businesses seeking to harness the full potential of AI. Unlike generic solutions, these bespoke models are tailored to address specific challenges and optimise performance in targeted areas. By aligning closely with a company's unique data sets and objectives, customised AI models deliver more accurate insights and enhanced operational efficiency.

The shift towards customised AI solutions is driven by the recognition that off-the-shelf tools often fall short of meeting the nuanced needs of each organisation. These tailored models can be fine-tuned for specific tasks, seamlessly integrated with existing systems, and designed to process unique data sets that reflect the intricacies of each business. For instance, a retail company might leverage a custom AI model to analyse consumer behaviour and optimise inventory management, whilst a healthcare provider could develop a bespoke solution to predict patient outcomes and refine treatment plans.This level of personalisation not only ensures higher accuracy but also provides a significant competitive advantage in today's data-driven landscape.

4. Small Language Models
------------------------

Small Language Models

Small Language Models (SLMs) have emerged as a formidable force in the realm of AI, offering a compelling alternative to their larger counterparts. These compact AI models, with parameter counts ranging from a few million to a few billion, are designed to process, understand and generate natural language content with remarkable efficiency. SLMs employ advanced techniques such as model compression, knowledge distillation and transfer learning to condense the broad capabilities of larger models into a more focused, domain-specific toolset.

One of the key advantages of SLMs is their ability to operate in resource-constrained environments, making them ideal for edge devices and mobile applications. For instance, Granite 3.0 1B-A400M and Granite 3.0 3B-A800M boast total parameter counts of 1 billion and 3 billion respectively, yet their active parameter counts at inference are a mere 400 million and 800 million.

This reduction in parameters translates to decreased processing times and lower latency, allowing SLMs to respond swiftly to user queries. Moreover, their compact nature makes them more environmentally sustainable and cost-effective, as they consume less energy and require fewer computational resources compared to their larger counterparts.

3.AI for workplace productivity
-------------------------------

AI for workplace productivity

AI is revolutionising workplace productivity, offering a plethora of tools designed to streamline tasks and enhance efficiency across various sectors. From automating mundane administrative duties to providing sophisticated data analysis, AI-powered solutions are transforming how businesses operate in the digital age.

One notable example is Notion AI, an intelligent feature integrated into the popular workspace platform. This innovative tool assists users in generating content, answering queries and autofilling tables within their Notion pages. By leveraging AI capabilities, Notion enables teams to brainstorm more effectively, draft documents with greater speed and manage projects with increased precision.

Similarly, Otter.ai has emerged as a game-changer in the realm of meeting productivity. This AI-powered assistant offers real-time transcription, speaker identification and audio-text synchronisation, allowing professionals to focus on discussions rather than note-taking. These advancements not only save time but also enhance the quality of work output, demonstrating the tangible benefits of AI in boosting workplace efficiency.

2. Gen AI democratisation
-------------------------

Gen AI

Gen AI has emerged as a powerful force in democratising innovation, placing sophisticated tools in the hands of individuals across various sectors. This technological leap forward has significantly lowered the barriers to entry for creative and analytical endeavours, enabling a broader range of users to harness AI's capabilities without extensive technical expertise.

The impact of this democratisation is particularly evident in the business world, where Gartner predicts that by 2026, more than 80% of enterprises will be using Gen AI APIs and models in production environments, a stark increase from less than 5% in 2023.

This shift signifies a move towards more inclusive and efficient business practices, with AI tools being integrated into everyday applications. For instance, sales teams can now utilise AI-powered chatbots and proposal generators to streamline their operations, enhancing productivity without the need for extensive data science teams.

However, this widespread adoption is not without its challenges. A Boston Consulting Group study revealed that over half of executives surveyed are actively discouraging the use of generative AI due to a lack of understanding, whilst 37% are in a state of experimentation without proper policies or controls in place.

1. Multimodal AI
----------------

![Image 4: Youtube Placeholder](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/fD9SiYSpiwE/hqdefault.jpg)

Multimodal AI represents a significant leap forward in AI, combining various data types such as text, images, audio, and video to create a more comprehensive understanding of the world. Unlike traditional unimodal systems that rely on a single data type, multimodal AI integrates diverse inputs, enabling it to perform complex tasks with greater accuracy and contextual awareness.

At its core, multimodal AI comprises three key components: the input module, fusion module, and output module. The input module consists of multiple unimodal neural networks, each handling a different data type. The fusion module then processes and aligns the information from each modality, employing techniques such as early fusion to concatenate raw data. Finally, the output module delivers results that are often richer and more nuanced than those produced by unimodal systems

With that, here are the eight most important AI trends happening right now:

### 1. Big Tech Enters an AI Arms Race

In 2024 big tech started to invest serious amounts of capital into AI.

This includes large-scale investment into projects [like Google's all-in approach to AI search](https://www.wsj.com/tech/ai/google-generative-ai-search-summaries-announcement-ffab4ce1).

**However, big tech companies are also backing startups in the AI space.**
