### 2. Companies Race to Develop AI Search

AI tools that use [large language models (LLMs)](https://www.techopedia.com/definition/34948/large-language-model-llm) have the potential to change how people find information online.

(And potentially disrupt Google's [dominance of the search market](https://www.statista.com/statistics/216573/worldwide-market-share-of-search-engines/)).

***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/z13rawVHSN2psVJk9ITL)  
Interest in “AI search” has grown significantly in 2024.***

![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/z13rawVHSN2psVJk9ITL)

The underlying LLMs behind an interface like ChatGPT work by first analyzing large amounts of information and “learning” it. From this, the model recognizes patterns and can predict words and phrases that are meant to go together.

So, when a person types in a search query in natural language, the AI search platform can predict a sequence of human language that will answer the question.

**Instead of producing a list of relevant websites, the tool gives written answers pulled from a combination of different sources.**

And, these platforms go way beyond simple queries like finding the capital of Brazil or the current temperature.

Users can query broad questions like how to plan a dinner party meal or find a car to buy.

In this way, AI search is another form of [generative AI](https://explodingtopics.com/topic/generative-ai): AI that can create new content like images, audio, code, and, in this case, text.

***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/JwAZyD8T6qneKgZI1NEs)  
Search volume for “generative AI” is exploding.***

![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/JwAZyD8T6qneKgZI1NEs)

[ChatGPT](https://www.cnet.com/tech/computing/why-were-all-obsessed-with-the-mind-blowing-chatgpt-ai-chatbot/) is a generative AI platform that went viral at the end of 2022.

Generative AI platforms like ChatGPT allow users to enter a question into the tool and it will provide an answer.

That means it can have very human-like conversations and complete commands to generate content.

However, most AI platforms are not built primarily for answering search queries.

**Which is why a number of companies are attempting to replace "10 blue links" with AI answers.**

For example, "AI search engine" [Perplexity AI](https://www.perplexity.ai/).

***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/yiFP71CwSBChvDOVVcsZ)  
Searches for "Perplexity AI" have increased significantly over the last two years.***

![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/yiFP71CwSBChvDOVVcsZ)

[Perplexity’s AI search chatbot](https://www.pcguide.com/apps/perplexity-ai/) can provide information in real time and it provides citations for the information.

Perplexity has raised [$165M in VC funding to date](https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/perplexity-ai). Notably, the platform has a passionate group of regular users (maybe of which are using Perplexity in place of Google search).

However, Perplexity is facing a significant threat: **big tech players have now entered the race to become the go-to generative AI search platform.**

Microsoft debuted their [AI-powered version of Bing](https://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-taps-chatgpt-to-improve-bing-and-the-edge-browser/) in early February 2023.

Although it’s run by ChatGPT technology, Microsoft claims it’s even faster and more accurate because it’s specifically built for search.

The platform allows users to ask follow up questions to a search and it can also generate new content.

Google has rolled out "AI Overviews" to many users.

***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/rbjjQVAQaaW7nOPDPl8Q)  
Google's AI overviews provide searchers a direct answer to their query (with links to sources).***

![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/rbjjQVAQaaW7nOPDPl8Q)

Despite the early popularity of these tools, many in the industry are quick to point out that AI search chatbots are in their infancy.

And in the case of Google's AI overviews, [there are still many accuracy hurdles to work through](https://www.tomshardware.com/tech-industry/artificial-intelligence/cringe-worth-google-ai-overviews).

### 3. Natural Language Processing Drives New Use Cases for AI

Few things in the AI industry have more promising business use cases than natural language processing (NLP).

***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/152CfchRaOBZmnbBzK0F)  
Search volume for “natural language processing” is growing.***

![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/152CfchRaOBZmnbBzK0F)

Our world is wrapped in text. Analyzing, formatting, translating, and using texts is essential to all types of business around the world.

And it’s not just words. NLP is being used to [analyze data](https://www.linguamatics.com/what-text-mining-text-analytics-and-natural-language-processing) in ways that are far different from prior statistical methods we’ve used.

***![nlp-tool-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/TAU5frk4SVquQhZAs5O7)  
With an NLP tool, organizations can process data up to 10x faster and analyze unstructured data via human language.***

![nlp-tool-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/TAU5frk4SVquQhZAs5O7)

So, what is NLP?

It's basically a way for [computers to speak human language](https://www.techtarget.com/searchenterpriseai/definition/natural-language-processing-NLP).

In the past, computers were only able to understand human language if it was first translated into code. But by using NLP, machines are able to gain intelligence from text as it sits in its natural state.

Estimates show the [amount of data in the world](https://explodingtopics.com/blog/data-generated-per-day) could hit [612 zettabytes](https://www.statista.com/chart/17727/global-data-creation-forecasts/) by 2030 and 2,142 zettabytes by 2035.

Much of this is human-readable text, so businesses can use NLP in order to determine the sentiment of text, [classify text](https://monkeylearn.com/what-is-text-classification/), extract meaning and keywords from text, and analyze text.

This provides an efficient way to analyze and gain insights from enormous amounts of data — something that just isn’t possible without the use of NLP.

[MonkeyLearn](https://monkeylearn.com) is an AI text analysis tool that can analyze reviews, surveys, support tickets, and other sources of human text.

***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/BzrDUGu9S12PBysIdbd3)

![monkeylearn-studio-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/ptJK0dYiScW6mTsu0loE)

For example, a company called [BlackBoiler](https://www.blackboiler.com/) offers AI technology that uses NLP to analyze contracts and suggest changes in places where clauses might be disputed.

The platform does all of this through a process that’s similar to “track changes” in a word processor program.

### 6. Computer Vision Boosts Efficiency Across Industries

[Computer vision](https://www.sas.com/en_us/insights/analytics/computer-vision.html) is a segment of AI that allows computers to interpret information from images and videos, and act on that information.

Today’s computer vision systems are more accurate than humans and react quicker than humans.

For example, computer vision [boosts defect detection in manufacturing by 90%](https://www.sas.com/content/dam/SAS/documents/infographics/2019/en-computer-vision-110208.pdf).

It can be used for everything from monitoring pipelines and crops to identifying counterfeit money and areas of concern in cancer patients.

***![computer-vision-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/2Bp7KdBJQ4yqumhMKbkm)  
Computer vision technology has far-reaching implications.***

![computer-vision-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/2Bp7KdBJQ4yqumhMKbkm)

While the concept of computer vision has been around since the 1950s, the advent of deep learning technology is enabling computer vision to be used in a wide range of applications that simply weren't possible in previous years.

In one survey, [nearly 30% of business leaders](https://www.shutterstock.com/developers/whitepaper-data-quality-for-trustworthy-computer-vision?utm_source=blog&utm_medium=blog&utm_campaign=computer-vision-whitepaper-2022&utm_campaignid=7013Z000002w6FhQAI) said they’ve seen a growing demand for computer vision solutions. More than half of them were most excited about object tracking and identification through computer vision.

Computer vision is one way in which manufacturers are jumping into the [Industry 4.0 trend](https://voxel51.com/blog/how-computer-vision-is-changing-manufacturing-in-2023/).

***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/ujrdWXKoRNUgMpLudKKA)  
Search interest for “AI in manufacturing” is up 480% in the past 5 years.***

![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/ujrdWXKoRNUgMpLudKKA)

This is an industry that’s suffering from huge staffing shortages. Up to [7.9 million manufacturing jobs](https://www.kornferry.com/content/dam/kornferry/docs/pdfs/KF-Future-of-Work-Talent-Crunch-Report.pdf) will go unfilled by 2030, resulting in unrealized revenue totaling $607.14 billion.

***![future-of-work-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/VnpO60fJR7S96Gd23fRL)  
The shortage of workers in manufacturing is expected to get much worse in the coming years.***

![future-of-work-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/VnpO60fJR7S96Gd23fRL)

By using computer vision, manufacturers are increasing the efficiency and performance of their facilities, as well as reducing staffing numbers.

[Detecting anomalies](https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/blog/business-operations-room-blog/2022/computer-vision-manufacturing-ai.html) is one important role of computer vision in manufacturing.

A computer vision system can track every step of the production process. If a step is missed or something is done out of order, an alarm is set off.

In addition, the system knows how long a production cycle should take and can detect faults if the cycle runs too fast.

Finally, when a faulty product is detected, workers can look up the item by its serial number to watch exactly what happened during the manufacturing process.

[Instrumental](https://instrumental.com/) offers an AI/computer vision system that provides issue discovery and quality monitoring for electronics manufacturers. The system also performs end-to-end failure analysis.

***![instrumental-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/qpY4wu4TFCRHjKWijFgm)  
Instrumental’s AI system allows manufacturers to find problems and fix them fast.***

![instrumental-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/qpY4wu4TFCRHjKWijFgm)

According to the company, their system results in a 43% reduction in rework and a 3x gain in product engineering efficiency.

Companies that install the system see a positive ROI in less than 60 days, they say.

Computer vision is also being deployed in response to natural disasters and climate change issues.

One California startup, aptly named [Rain](https://www.rain.aero/), is using computer vision to fight wildfires.

***![rain-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/FZmlGQoURbKeBYTGX2JY)  
Rain’s aircraft is able to stay in the air for over an hour.***

![rain-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/FZmlGQoURbKeBYTGX2JY)

Their product is an [unmanned autonomous helicopter](https://verticalmag.com/press-releases/rain-industries-announces-autonomous-firefighting-helicopter/) that uses AI and computer vision to deliver water to a wildfire before it grows out of control.

The company’s idea is to put these helicopters in high-risk areas that aren’t staffed by humans 24/7. If a wildfire broke out, the helicopter could be immediately deployed by a pilot at a remote location.

The project will be tested this year on real fires in California and the company projects they’ll build [200 helicopter stations](https://qz.com/firetech-forest-wildfire-startup-technology-1850205150) there.

In addition, a team at the University of Cambridge recently developed a [computer vision system](https://www.zmescience.com/science/this-new-app-can-measure-trees-much-faster-than-manual-methods/) that allows scientists to monitor forests and carbon sequestration from their smartphones.

***![zmescience-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/rQXYuL5oSmKRId1nk5ro)  
The computer vision system developed by the University of Cambridge utilizes LiDAR sensors.***

At the same time as it’s being deployed in a wide variety of industries, the technology of computer vision itself is being revolutionized.

Today’s computer vision works by taking an image or series of images in still frames. Then the still frames are analyzed by the computer.

However, one company is imagining computer vision that doesn’t need still frames.

[Ubicept](https://www.ubicept.com/), a company formed in 2021, has developed computer vision that can [measure individual photons](https://techcrunch.com/2023/03/10/ubicept-computer-vision/) instead of looking at still frames.

That process is faster and more reliable than traditional computer vision.

It’s especially beneficial for situations in which the camera needs to capture objects moving fast or objects in low light.

***![ubicept-computer-vision-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/xancjTS2R6GWwntj2yQ1)  
Ubicept’s [computer vision technology](https://www.ubicept.com/blog/viva-las-vegas) excels in low light and fast motion, two areas in which traditional computer vision falls short.***

### 7. Retailers Deploy AI In-Store and Online

The retail sector is one that could potentially reap huge benefits from the use of AI.

As of 2024, [40% of retailers are already using AI in some form](https://www.statista.com/statistics/1400301/ai-mv-and-cv-use-retail/).

And the use of AI is continuing to grow.

Location-based marketing, digital devices, and computer vision also made the list with more than one-third of retailers saying they’ll focus on those tech solutions in the next two years.

***![retail-tech-study-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/wMrroMMT9KrNnfwkDr8m)

One of the most obvious uses of [AI in retail](https://mobidev.biz/blog/how-to-implement-ai-self-checkout-in-retail-if-you-are-not-amazon) is at checkout.

Stores like Amazon Go track customers through the store via computer vision. When a person puts an item in a physical cart, the computer vision catches which product it is and adds it to a virtual cart of sorts. When the person leaves the store, their digital wallet is charged accordingly.

Retailers are also using [AI for inventory management](https://addepto.com/blog/ai-in-inventory-management/).

AI systems can monitor stock levels in the warehouse and on shelves. When stock is running low, the system can automatically notify the proper channels and decrease the time it takes to replenish the product supply.

McKinsey reports that businesses that adopt [AI-enabled supply chains](https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/succeeding-in-the-ai-supply-chain-revolution) see a 15% improvement in logistics costs and a 35% improvement in inventory levels.

AI also enables retailers to utilize dynamic pricing.

With data from the retailer, competitors, and customers, AI can be used to [adjust pricing in real time](https://segwitz.com/the-impact-of-artificial-intelligence-on-the-retail-industry/) and maximize profits.

Retailers that use electronic shelf labels and AI-enabled dynamic pricing have the potential to [increase profit by 33%](https://revionics.com/blog/electronic-shelf-labels-price-optimization).

One of the most recent developments for retailers is generative AI.

For instance, [Shopify Magic](https://www.shopify.com/blog/ai-product-descriptions) was released in early 2023 as a tool that will write ecommerce product descriptions for retailers.

***![shopify-magic-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/yGcK6lwTsuV91KIEpWkI)  
Shopify Magic enables retailers to create product descriptions in seconds.***

![shopify-magic-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/yGcK6lwTsuV91KIEpWkI)

Shopify says they’ll be adding more tools with AI in the near future.

Retailers are also utilizing generative AI to create in-store displays.

By inserting a few prompts into a program like DALL-E, retailers can come up with a visual concept and merchandising imagery.

One retailer said her team typically spends a week brainstorming and [creating imagery for a new in-store design](https://www.retailtouchpoints.com/topics/retail-store-design/in-store-innovation/how-store-design-teams-are-unlocking-tangible-value-from-ai-platforms).

With AI, they were able to do it in just eight hours.

***![apparel-store-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/miNTwDsQwuXOgkxvxqk9)  
An example of an AI-generated concept for a luxury fashion store.***

![apparel-store-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/miNTwDsQwuXOgkxvxqk9)

Apparel companies are also using generative AI to create hundreds of recommended outfit combinations that appear on their websites and apps.

By working with the company [Stylitics](https://stylitics.com/), Puma was able to [increase conversions by 235%](https://www.retailtouchpoints.com/topics/inventory-merchandising/puma-using-ai-powered-styling-brainstorm-with-customers-increase-aov-stylitics-visual-merchandising) and session duration by 334%.

***![stylitics-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/dlbVFvjUSQuqqNqPl5Cu)  
Stylitics’ AI-powered solution puts together outfit combinations and replaces outfit pieces as they go out of stock.***

![stylitics-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/dlbVFvjUSQuqqNqPl5Cu)

### 8. Increasing Potential for AI Risks and Regulations

As AI adoption has increased, the level of risk mitigation has remained the same.

This means that many enterprises aren’t paying attention to the risks associated with AI.

***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/WrGBbkv4TXatpu5TEUga)  
Search volume for “AI risks” is up more than 700% since 2019.***

![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/WrGBbkv4TXatpu5TEUga)

When looking at the past three years, a survey from McKinsey showed no substantial increase in the amount of attention companies are giving any [AI-related risks](https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/the-state-of-ai-in-2022-and-a-half-decade-in-review#review). This includes cybersecurity, regulatory compliance, privacy, and explainability.

***![mckinsey-state-of-ai-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/zEeklCxqSVax2XeuWNaP)  
McKinsey called the lack of focus on AI risks “concerning.”***

![mckinsey-state-of-ai-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/zEeklCxqSVax2XeuWNaP)

The list of [potential risks](https://ai100.stanford.edu/2021-report/standing-questions-and-responses/sq10-what-are-most-pressing-dangers-ai) is long — and it keeps growing.

The Wharton School created an extensive paper outlining [the risks of using AI in business](https://aiab.wharton.upenn.edu/research/artificial-intelligence-risk-governance/). Poor data quality, data attacks, lack of transparency, and bias were just a few of the topics discussed.

In recent months, there have been signs from companies, consumers, and the US government showing a shifting focus toward these risks and AI safety.

Another report from McKinsey shows that [72% of consumers](https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/why-digital-trust-truly-matters) believe that it’s important to know a company’s AI policy before they make a purchase.

In that same survey, 55% of business leaders said they’d suffered an AI incident in the past three years.

In another survey, nearly [two-thirds of people in the US](https://www.protocol.com/policy/ai-regulation-seedai) said they wanted regulations placed on AI in the near future.

***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/H2OTihimSP6CrEuMR4Rn)  
Search volume for “AI regulation” has increased by more than 857% in recent years.***

![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/H2OTihimSP6CrEuMR4Rn)

However, outside of the EU, governments haven't been quick to offer up any laws or oversight.

As of May 2024, there haven’t been any bills proposed in Congress that would [limit the reach of AI](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/03/business/dealbook/lawmakers-ai-regulations.html).

In late 2022, the White House released an [AI Bill of Rights](https://www.whitehouse.gov/ostp/ai-bill-of-rights/) that was aimed at encouraging companies to police the use of AI within their ranks, but it has no authority.

***![ai-bill-of-rights-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/daBGBjpSSqi360zALzdt)  
The AI Bill of Rights encourages businesses to adequately assess their AI systems and correct potential problems.***

![ai-bill-of-rights-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/daBGBjpSSqi360zALzdt)

However, federal agencies are upping their involvement in AI regulation.

The FTC, FDA, and CFPB are all acting in some way to curb the use of unethical AI.

In one case, the [FTC took action against Weight Watchers](https://www.protocol.com/policy/ftc-algorithm-destroy-data-privacy) for improperly collecting information from children and creating AI models from the data.

More federal-level action on AI regulation has taken place in Europe.

***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/Tr0Dg0U7RCu0vbCf6wIO)  
Search interest in “AI Act” is up more than 2,200%.***

![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/Tr0Dg0U7RCu0vbCf6wIO)

***![ai-act-explainer-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/ViPp8I8XQLmgVcIHPyXD)  
The [AI Act](https://www.adalovelaceinstitute.org/resource/eu-ai-act-explainer/) looks at applications based on their level of potential risk.***

![ai-act-explainer-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/ViPp8I8XQLmgVcIHPyXD)

### Conclusion

That wraps up our list of the top AI trends to watch over the next few years.

Artificial intelligence, and the tech solutions it powers, will undoubtedly change the way businesses and individuals operate in the world.

In many industries, AI will drive the development of methods and processes that we’ve never seen before. This has the potential to increase efficiency, lessen the impact of the labor shortage, and prompt businesses to create new revenue streams.

However, the true risks of AI remain to be seen. In the coming years, the vulnerabilities of AI may be exposed, and governments, agencies, and consumers will have to decide how to balance the risks and benefits.

2025, AI continues to reshape industries and redefine the boundaries of technological innovation. The rapid evolution of AI has ushered in a new era of digital transformation, with generative AI leading the charge. Investment in this groundbreaking technology is projected by [PWC](https://aimagazine.com/articles/examining-the-big-openai-and-pwc-enterprise-deal) to contribute a staggering US$15.7tn to the global economy in 2030,underscoring its pivotal role in shaping the future of business and society.\\n\\nFrom revolutionising [healthcare](https://aimagazine.com/ai-applications/alphafold-3-google-deepmind-seeks-to-transform-healthcare) with AI-driven diagnostics to transforming [financial services](https://aimagazine.com/articles/ey-finance-leaders-turn-to-ai-to-solve-esg-data-problems) with intelligent algorithms, the impact of AI is far-reaching and profound.\\n\\nHowever, this technological leap forward also brings new challenges, particularly in the realms of ethics, regulation, and data security.\\n\\nIn light of this, AI Magazine presents a comprehensive list of the top 10 AI trends of 2024 to understand the AI developments of this year and gain a glimpse of what could be in store for 2025.\\n\\n10. AI governance and ethics\\n----------------------------\\n\\nAI governance and ethics\\n\\nAI governance and ethics have become paramount concerns as artificial intelligence technologies continue to reshape our world. The UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, adopted by 193 countries in 2021, stands as a cornerstone in this field. This comprehensive framework emphasises four core values: respect for human rights, fostering just societies, environmental well-being, and diversity and inclusiveness. It interprets AI broadly, recognising the rapid pace of technological change and the need for future-proof policies.\\n\\nThe recommendation outlines eleven key areas for policy actions, moving beyond high-level principles to practical strategies. These include sustainability, fairness, technical safety, accountability, explainability, and data stewardship. To support the implementation of these principles, UNESCO has established the Global AI Ethics and Governance Observatory. This platform serves as a vital resource for policymakers, regulators, academics, and civil society, offering country profiles, expert insights, and good practices in AI ethics and governance. The observatory\'s AI Ethics and Governance Lab gathers contributions, research, and toolkits to address pressing challenges in responsible AI innovation, standards, and institutional capacities.\\n\\n9.AI talent demand\\n------------------\\n\\nAI talent demand\\n\\nThe demand for AI talent has skyrocketed in recent years, with job postings incorporating AI skills as a requirement surging by 130% over the last two years. This trend is particularly evident in the field of generative AI, where roles have seen an unprecedented 1,300% increase in demand. The surge reflects the critical importance of AI expertise in today\'s rapidly evolving tech landscape, with machine learning and data science roles growing by 80% and 250%, respectively.\\n\\nThis dramatic shift in the job market has led to a significant skills shortage, with the International Data Corporation predicting that over 90% of companies will face IT skills shortages by 2026. In response, organisations are increasingly looking beyond traditional talent pools, with a 31% increase in demand for specialised skills across borders. This global approach to talent acquisition is reshaping recruitment strategies, as companies seek to build teams with the specialised skills needed to develop and implement AI-driven solutions. The trend towards skills-based hiring is further emphasised by the fact that 80% of companies are now prioritising becoming skills-based organisations, with a particular focus on AI and related technologies.\\n\\n7. Open source AI\\n-----------------\\n\\nOpen Source AI\\n\\nOpen source AI has emerged as a powerful force in the realm of technology, fostering collaboration and innovation on a global scale. This approach to AI development allows researchers, developers and organisations to freely access, modify and distribute AI systems, including datasets, code and model parameters. The transparency inherent in open source AI has led to significant advancements in various fields, from natural language processing to computer vision.\\n\\nOne of the most notable examples of open source AI is OpenCV, the Open Source Computer Vision Library. Launched in 1999 as part of an Intel research project, OpenCV has since become a cornerstone in the computer vision community. Its extensive library of algorithms supports a wide array of applications, including facial recognition, object detection and motion tracking. The longevity and versatility of OpenCV underscore the enduring impact of open source AI initiatives. Another prominent player in the open source AI landscape is OpenNN, a neural network library that excels in predictive analytics. Developed by Artelnics, OpenNN has found applications in customer intelligence and industry-specific analytics, demonstrating the practical value of open source AI in business contexts.\\n\\n7. Agentic AI\\n-------------\\n\\nAgentic AI\\n\\nAgentic AI represents a significant leap forward in artificial intelligence, offering a level of autonomy and decision-making capability that sets it apart from traditional AI systems. This advanced form of AI is designed to operate independently, making decisions and adapting to changing environments with minimal human intervention. Unlike its predecessors, agentic AI can analyse complex situations, formulate strategies and execute multi-step tasks to achieve predefined goals. At its core, agentic AI employs sophisticated algorithms that enable it to understand and interpret natural language instructions, develop action plans and adjust its approach based on real-time feedback.\\n\\nThis adaptability allows it to optimise workflows, enhance customer service experiences and streamline operations across various industries. For instance, in financial services, agentic AI excels at fraud detection by analysing vast amounts of data and autonomously initiating resolution workflows when issues are identified. Its ability to learn from interactions and improve over time positions agentic AI as a powerful tool for enterprises seeking to boost efficiency and maintain a competitive edge in an increasingly dynamic marketplace.\\n\\n6.AI in scientific research\\n---------------------------\\n\\nAI in scientific research\\n\\nAI is rapidly transforming scientific research across numerous disciplines, offering unprecedented capabilities in data analysis, hypothesis generation, and experimental design. In genomics, AI algorithms can swiftly analyse genetic sequences to identify disease markers, whilst in drug discovery, machine learning models predict the efficacy of new compounds with remarkable accuracy. These advancements have led to significant time and cost reductions in research processes, with genomics seeing a 60% acceleration in research and a 50% reduction in costs.\\n\\nThe integration of AI in scientific research extends beyond data analysis. Natural Language Processing (NLP) systems are revolutionising how researchers manage the ever-growing volume of scientific literature. These AI-powered tools can summarise vast collections of research papers, extracting key findings and methodologies, thus enabling scientists to stay abreast of developments in their field without the need to read through entire papers. Moreover, AI is fostering interdisciplinary research by integrating data and methodologies from different scientific fields, leading to innovative solutions for complex problems such as climate change and its socioeconomic impacts.\\n\\n5.Customisable AI\\n-----------------\\n\\nCustomisable AI\\n\\nCustomisable AI models have emerged as a powerful tool for businesses seeking to harness the full potential of AI. Unlike generic solutions, these bespoke models are tailored to address specific challenges and optimise performance in targeted areas. By aligning closely with a company\'s unique data sets and objectives, customised AI models deliver more accurate insights and enhanced operational efficiency.\\n\\nThe shift towards customised AI solutions is driven by the recognition that off-the-shelf tools often fall short of meeting the nuanced needs of each organisation. These tailored models can be fine-tuned for specific tasks, seamlessly integrated with existing systems, and designed to process unique data sets that reflect the intricacies of each business. For instance, a retail company might leverage a custom AI model to analyse consumer behaviour and optimise inventory management, whilst a healthcare provider could develop a bespoke solution to predict patient outcomes and refine treatment plans.This level of personalisation not only ensures higher accuracy but also provides a significant competitive advantage in today\'s data-driven landscape.\\n\\n4. Small Language Models\\n------------------------\\n\\nSmall Language Models\\n\\nSmall Language Models (SLMs) have emerged as a formidable force in the realm of AI, offering a compelling alternative to their larger counterparts. These compact AI models, with parameter counts ranging from a few million to a few billion, are designed to process, understand and generate natural language content with remarkable efficiency. SLMs employ advanced techniques such as model compression, knowledge distillation and transfer learning to condense the broad capabilities of larger models into a more focused, domain-specific toolset.\\n\\nOne of the key advantages of SLMs is their ability to operate in resource-constrained environments, making them ideal for edge devices and mobile applications. For instance, Granite 3.0 1B-A400M and Granite 3.0 3B-A800M boast total parameter counts of 1 billion and 3 billion respectively, yet their active parameter counts at inference are a mere 400 million and 800 million.\\n\\nThis reduction in parameters translates to decreased processing times and lower latency, allowing SLMs to respond swiftly to user queries. Moreover, their compact nature makes them more environmentally sustainable and cost-effective, as they consume less energy and require fewer computational resources compared to their larger counterparts.\\n\\n3.AI for workplace productivity\\n-------------------------------\\n\\nAI for workplace productivity\\n\\nAI is revolutionising workplace productivity, offering a plethora of tools designed to streamline tasks and enhance efficiency across various sectors. From automating mundane administrative duties to providing sophisticated data analysis, AI-powered solutions are transforming how businesses operate in the digital age.\\n\\nOne notable example is Notion AI, an intelligent feature integrated into the popular workspace platform. This innovative tool assists users in generating content, answering queries and autofilling tables within their Notion pages. By leveraging AI capabilities, Notion enables teams to brainstorm more effectively, draft documents with greater speed and manage projects with increased precision.\\n\\nSimilarly, Otter.ai has emerged as a game-changer in the realm of meeting productivity. This AI-powered assistant offers real-time transcription, speaker identification and audio-text synchronisation, allowing professionals to focus on discussions rather than note-taking. These advancements not only save time but also enhance the quality of work output, demonstrating the tangible benefits of AI in boosting workplace efficiency.\\n\\n2. Gen AI democratisation\\n-------------------------\\n\\nGen AI\\n\\nGen AI has emerged as a powerful force in democratising innovation, placing sophisticated tools in the hands of individuals across various sectors. This technological leap forward has significantly lowered the barriers to entry for creative and analytical endeavours, enabling a broader range of users to harness AI\'s capabilities without extensive technical expertise.\\n\\nThe impact of this democratisation is particularly evident in the business world, where Gartner predicts that by 2026, more than 80% of enterprises will be using Gen AI APIs and models in production environments, a stark increase from less than 5% in 2023.\\n\\nThis shift signifies a move towards more inclusive and efficient business practices, with AI tools being integrated into everyday applications. For instance, sales teams can now utilise AI-powered chatbots and proposal generators to streamline their operations, enhancing productivity without the need for extensive data science teams.\\n\\nHowever, this widespread adoption is not without its challenges. A Boston Consulting Group study revealed that over half of executives surveyed are actively discouraging the use of generative AI due to a lack of understanding, whilst 37% are in a state of experimentation without proper policies or controls in place.\\n\\n1. Multimodal AI\\n----------------\\n\\n![Image 4: Youtube Placeholder](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/fD9SiYSpiwE/hqdefault.jpg)\\n\\nMultimodal AI represents a significant leap forward in AI, combining various data types such as text, images, audio, and video to create a more comprehensive understanding of the world. Unlike traditional unimodal systems that rely on a single data type, multimodal AI integrates diverse inputs, enabling it to perform complex tasks with greater accuracy and contextual awareness.\\n\\nAt its core, multimodal AI comprises three key components: the input module, fusion module, and output module. The input module consists of multiple unimodal neural networks, each handling a different data type. The fusion module then processes and aligns the information from each modality, employing techniques such as early fusion to concatenate raw data. Companies Race to Develop AI Search\\n\\nAI tools that use\xa0[large language models (LLMs)](https://www.techopedia.com/definition/34948/large-language-model-llm) have the potential to change how people find information online.\\n\\n(And potentially disrupt Google\'s [dominance of the search market](https://www.statista.com/statistics/216573/worldwide-market-share-of-search-engines/)).\\n\\n***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/z13rawVHSN2psVJk9ITL)  \\nInterest in “AI search” has grown significantly in 2024.***\\n\\n![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/z13rawVHSN2psVJk9ITL)\\n\\nThe underlying LLMs behind an interface like ChatGPT work by first analyzing large amounts of information and “learning” it. From this, the model recognizes patterns and can predict words and phrases that are meant to go together.\\n\\nSo, when a person types in a search query in natural language, the AI search platform can predict a sequence of human language that will answer the question.\\n\\n**Instead of producing a list of relevant websites, the tool gives written answers pulled from a combination of different sources.**\\n\\nAnd, these platforms go way beyond simple queries like finding the capital of Brazil or the current temperature.\\n\\nUsers can query broad questions like how to plan a dinner party meal\xa0or find a car to buy.\\n\\nIn this way, AI search is another form of\xa0[generative AI](https://explodingtopics.com/topic/generative-ai): AI that can create new content like images, audio, code, and, in this case, text.\\n\\n***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/JwAZyD8T6qneKgZI1NEs)  \\nSearch volume for “generative AI” is exploding.***\\n\\n![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/JwAZyD8T6qneKgZI1NEs)\\n\\n[ChatGPT](https://www.cnet.com/tech/computing/why-were-all-obsessed-with-the-mind-blowing-chatgpt-ai-chatbot/) is a generative AI platform that went viral at the end of 2022.\\n\\nGenerative AI platforms like ChatGPT allow users to enter a question into the tool and it will provide an answer.\\n\\nThat means it can have very human-like conversations and complete commands to generate content.\\n\\nHowever, most AI platforms are not built primarily for answering search queries.\\n\\n**Which is why a number Notably, the platform has a passionate group of regular users (maybe of which are using Perplexity in place of Google search).\\n\\nHowever, Perplexity is facing a significant threat: **big tech players have now entered the race to become the go-to generative AI search platform.**\\n\\nMicrosoft debuted their [AI-powered version of Bing](https://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-taps-chatgpt-to-improve-bing-and-the-edge-browser/) in early February 2023.\\n\\nAlthough it’s run by ChatGPT technology, Microsoft claims it’s even faster and more accurate because it’s specifically built for search.\\n\\nThe platform allows users to ask follow up questions to a search and it can also generate new content.\\n\\nGoogle has rolled out \\"AI Overviews\\" to many users.\\n\\n***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/rbjjQVAQaaW7nOPDPl8Q)  \\nGoogle\'s AI overviews provide searchers a direct answer to their query (with links to sources).***\\n\\n![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/rbjjQVAQaaW7nOPDPl8Q)\\n\\nDespite the early popularity of these tools, many in the industry are quick to point out that AI search chatbots are in their infancy.\\n\\nAnd in the case of Google\'s AI overviews, [there are still many accuracy hurdles\xa0to work through](https://www.tomshardware.com/tech-industry/artificial-intelligence/cringe-worth-google-ai-overviews).\\n\\n### 3. Natural Language Processing Drives New Use Cases for AI\\n\\nFew things in the AI industry have more promising business use cases than natural language processing (NLP).\\n\\n***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/152CfchRaOBZmnbBzK0F)  \\nSearch volume for “natural language processing” is growing.***\\n\\n![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/152CfchRaOBZmnbBzK0F)\\n\\nOur world is wrapped in text. Analyzing, formatting, translating, and using texts is essential to all types of business around the world.\\n\\nAnd it’s not just words. NLP is being used to [analyze data](https://www.linguamatics.com/what-text-mining-text-analytics-and-natural-language-processing) in ways that are far different from prior statistical methods we’ve used.\\n\\n***![nlp-tool-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/TAU5frk4SVquQhZAs5O7)  \\nWith an NLP tool, organizations can process data up to 10x faster and analyze unstructured data via human language.***\\n\\n![nlp-tool-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/TAU5frk4SVquQhZAs5O7)\\n\\nSo, what is NLP?\\n\\nIt\'s basically a way for [computers to speak human language](https://www.techtarget.com/searchenterpriseai/definition/natural-language-processing-NLP).\\n\\nIn the past, computers were only able to understand human language if it was first translated into code. But by using NLP, machines are able to gain intelligence from text as it sits in its natural state.\\n\\nEstimates show the [amount of data in the world](https://explodingtopics.com/blog/data-generated-per-day) could hit [612 zettabytes](https://www.statista.com/chart/17727/global-data-creation-forecasts/) by 2030 and 2,142 zettabytes by 2035.\\n\\nMuch of this is human-readable text, so businesses can use NLP in order to determine the sentiment of text, [classify text](https://monkeylearn.com/what-is-text-classification/), extract meaning and keywords from text, and analyze text.\\n\\nThis provides an efficient way to analyze and gain insights from enormous amounts of data — something that just isn’t possible without the use of NLP.\\n\\n[MonkeyLearn](https://monkeylearn.com) is an AI text analysis tool that can analyze reviews, surveys, support tickets, and other sources of human text.\\n\\n***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/BzrDUGu9S12PBysIdbd3)  \\nSearches for “MonkeyLearn” are up 200% in the past 5 emails, reviews, social media, and other sources.***\\n\\n![monkeylearn-studio-min.webp](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/ptJK0dYiScW6mTsu0loE)\\n\\nIn the legal and commercial space, dozens of The rapid evolution of AI has ushered in a new era of digital transformation, with generative AI leading the charge. Investment in this groundbreaking technology is projected by [PWC](https://aimagazine.com/articles/examining-the-big-openai-and-pwc-enterprise-deal) to contribute a staggering US$15.7tn to the global economy in 2030,underscoring its pivotal role in shaping the future of business and society.\\\\n\\\\nFrom revolutionising [healthcare](https://aimagazine.com/ai-applications/alphafold-3-google-deepmind-seeks-to-transform-healthcare) with AI-driven diagnostics to transforming [financial services](https://aimagazine.com/articles/ey-finance-leaders-turn-to-ai-to-solve-esg-data-problems) with intelligent algorithms, the impact of AI is far-reaching and profound.\\\\n\\\\nHowever, this technological leap forward also brings new challenges, particularly in the realms of ethics, regulation, and data security.\\\\n\\\\nIn light of this, AI Magazine presents a comprehensive list of the top 10 AI trends of 2024 to understand the AI developments of this year and gain a glimpse of what could be in store for 2025.\\\\n\\\\n10. AI governance and ethics\\\\n----------------------------\\\\n\\\\nAI governance and ethics\\\\n\\\\nAI governance and ethics have become paramount concerns as artificial intelligence technologies continue to reshape our world. The UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, adopted by 193 countries in 2021, stands as a cornerstone in this field. This comprehensive framework emphasises four core values: respect for human rights, fostering just societies, environmental well-being, and diversity and inclusiveness. It interprets AI broadly, recognising the rapid pace of technological change and the need for future-proof policies.\\\\n\\\\nThe recommendation outlines eleven key areas for policy actions, moving beyond high-level principles to practical strategies. These include sustainability, fairness, technical safety, accountability, explainability, and data stewardship. To support the implementation of these principles, UNESCO has established the Global AI Ethics and Governance Observatory. This platform serves as a vital resource for policymakers, regulators, academics, and civil society, offering country profiles, expert insights, and good practices in AI ethics and governance. The observatory\\'s AI Ethics and Governance Lab gathers contributions, research, and toolkits to address pressing challenges in responsible AI innovation, standards, and institutional capacities.\\\\n\\\\n9.AI talent demand\\\\n------------------\\\\n\\\\nAI talent demand\\\\n\\\\nThe demand for AI talent has skyrocketed in recent years, with job postings incorporating AI skills as a requirement surging by 130% over the last two years. This trend is particularly evident in the field of generative AI, where roles have seen an unprecedented 1,300% increase in demand. The surge reflects the critical importance of AI expertise in today\\'s rapidly evolving tech landscape, with machine learning and data science roles growing by 80% and 250%, respectively.\\\\n\\\\nThis dramatic shift in the job market has led to a significant skills shortage, with the International Data Corporation predicting that over 90% of companies will face IT skills shortages by 2026. In response, organisations are increasingly looking beyond traditional talent pools, with a 31% increase in demand for specialised skills across borders. This global approach to talent acquisition is reshaping recruitment strategies, as companies seek to build teams with the specialised skills needed to develop and implement AI-driven solutions. The trend towards skills-based hiring is further emphasised by the fact that 80% of companies are now prioritising becoming skills-based organisations, with a particular focus on AI and related technologies.\\\\n\\\\n7. Open source AI\\\\n-----------------\\\\n\\\\nOpen Source AI\\\\n\\\\nOpen source AI has emerged as a powerful force in the realm of technology, fostering collaboration and innovation on a global scale. This approach to AI development allows researchers, developers and organisations to freely access, modify and distribute AI systems, including datasets, code and model parameters. The transparency inherent in open source AI has led to significant advancements in various fields, from natural language processing to computer vision.\\\\n\\\\nOne of the most notable examples of open source AI is OpenCV, the Open Source Computer Vision Library. Launched in 1999 as part of an Intel research project, OpenCV has since become a cornerstone in the computer vision community. Its extensive library of algorithms supports a wide array of applications, including facial recognition, object detection and motion tracking. The longevity and versatility of OpenCV underscore the enduring impact of open source AI initiatives. Another prominent player in the open source AI landscape is OpenNN, a neural network library that excels in predictive analytics. Developed by Artelnics, OpenNN has found applications in customer intelligence and industry-specific analytics, demonstrating the practical value of open source AI in business contexts.\\\\n\\\\n7. Agentic AI\\\\n-------------\\\\n\\\\nAgentic AI\\\\n\\\\nAgentic AI represents a significant leap forward in artificial intelligence, offering a level of autonomy and decision-making capability that sets it apart from traditional AI systems. This advanced form of AI is designed to operate independently, making decisions and adapting to changing environments with minimal human intervention. Unlike its predecessors, agentic AI can analyse complex situations, formulate strategies and execute multi-step tasks to achieve predefined goals. At its core, agentic AI employs sophisticated algorithms that enable it to understand and interpret natural language instructions, develop action plans and adjust its approach based on real-time feedback.\\\\n\\\\nThis adaptability allows it to optimise workflows, enhance customer service experiences and streamline operations across various industries. For instance, in financial services, agentic AI excels at fraud detection by analysing vast amounts of data and autonomously initiating resolution workflows when issues are identified. Its ability to learn from interactions and improve over time positions agentic AI as a powerful tool for enterprises seeking to boost efficiency and maintain a competitive edge in an increasingly dynamic marketplace.\\\\n\\\\n6.AI in scientific research\\\\n---------------------------\\\\n\\\\nAI in scientific research\\\\n\\\\nAI is rapidly transforming scientific research across numerous disciplines, offering unprecedented capabilities in data analysis, hypothesis generation, and experimental design. In genomics, AI algorithms can swiftly analyse genetic sequences to identify disease markers, whilst in drug discovery, machine learning models predict the efficacy of new compounds with remarkable accuracy. These advancements have led to significant time and cost reductions in research processes, with genomics seeing a 60% acceleration in research and a 50% reduction in costs.\\\\n\\\\nThe integration of AI in scientific research extends beyond data analysis. Natural Language Processing (NLP) systems are revolutionising how researchers manage the ever-growing volume of scientific literature. These AI-powered tools can summarise vast collections of research papers, extracting key findings and methodologies, thus enabling scientists to stay abreast of developments in their field without the need to read through entire papers. Moreover, AI is fostering interdisciplinary research by integrating data and methodologies from different scientific fields, leading to innovative solutions for complex problems such as climate change and its socioeconomic impacts.\\\\n\\\\n5.Customisable AI\\\\n-----------------\\\\n\\\\nCustomisable AI\\\\n\\\\nCustomisable AI models have emerged as a powerful tool for businesses seeking to harness the full potential of AI. Unlike generic solutions, these bespoke models are tailored to address specific challenges and optimise performance in targeted areas. By aligning closely with a company\\'s unique data sets and objectives, customised AI models deliver more accurate insights and enhanced operational efficiency.\\\\n\\\\nThe shift towards customised AI solutions is driven by the recognition that off-the-shelf tools often fall short of meeting the nuanced needs of each organisation. These tailored models can be fine-tuned for specific tasks, seamlessly integrated with existing systems, and designed to process unique data sets that reflect the intricacies of each business. For instance, a retail company might leverage a custom AI model to analyse consumer behaviour and optimise inventory management, whilst a healthcare provider could develop a bespoke solution to predict patient outcomes and refine treatment plans.This level of personalisation not only ensures higher accuracy but also provides a significant competitive advantage in today\\'s data-driven landscape.\\\\n\\\\n4. Small Language Models\\\\n------------------------\\\\n\\\\nSmall Language Models\\\\n\\\\nSmall Language Models (SLMs) have emerged as a formidable force in the realm of AI, offering a compelling alternative to their larger counterparts. These compact AI models, with parameter counts ranging from a few million to a few billion, are designed to process, understand and generate natural language content with remarkable efficiency. SLMs employ advanced techniques such as model compression, knowledge distillation and transfer learning to condense the broad capabilities of larger models into a more focused, domain-specific toolset.\\\\n\\\\nOne of the key advantages of SLMs is their ability to operate in resource-constrained environments, making them ideal for edge devices and mobile applications. For instance, Granite 3.0 1B-A400M and Granite 3.0 3B-A800M boast total parameter counts of 1 billion and 3 billion respectively, yet their active parameter counts at inference are a mere 400 million and 800 million.\\\\n\\\\nThis reduction in parameters translates to decreased processing times and lower latency, allowing SLMs to respond swiftly to user queries. Moreover, their compact nature makes them more environmentally sustainable and cost-effective, as they consume less energy and require fewer computational resources compared to their larger counterparts.\\\\n\\\\n3.AI for workplace productivity\\\\n-------------------------------\\\\n\\\\nAI for workplace productivity\\\\n\\\\nAI is revolutionising workplace productivity, offering a plethora of tools designed to streamline tasks and enhance efficiency across various sectors. From automating mundane administrative duties to providing sophisticated data analysis, AI-powered solutions are transforming how businesses operate in the digital age.\\\\n\\\\nOne notable example is Notion AI, an intelligent feature integrated into the popular workspace platform. This innovative tool assists users in generating content, answering queries and autofilling tables within their Notion pages. By leveraging AI capabilities, Notion enables teams to brainstorm more effectively, draft documents with greater speed and manage projects with increased precision.\\\\n\\\\nSimilarly, Otter.ai has emerged as a game-changer in the realm of meeting productivity. This AI-powered assistant offers real-time transcription, speaker identification and audio-text synchronisation, allowing professionals to focus on discussions rather than note-taking. These advancements not only save time but also enhance the quality of work output, demonstrating the tangible benefits of AI in boosting workplace efficiency.\\\\n\\\\n2. Gen AI democratisation\\\\n-------------------------\\\\n\\\\nGen AI\\\\n\\\\nGen AI has emerged as a powerful force in democratising innovation, placing sophisticated tools in the hands of individuals across various sectors. This technological leap forward has significantly lowered the barriers to entry for creative and analytical endeavours, enabling a broader range of users to harness AI\\'s capabilities without extensive technical expertise.\\\\n\\\\nThe impact of this democratisation is particularly evident in the business world, where Gartner predicts that by 2026, more than 80% of enterprises will be using Gen AI APIs and models in production environments, a stark increase from less than 5% in 2023.\\\\n\\\\nThis shift signifies a move towards more inclusive and efficient business practices, with AI tools being integrated into everyday applications. For instance, sales teams can now utilise AI-powered chatbots and proposal generators to streamline their operations, enhancing productivity without the need for extensive data science teams.\\\\n\\\\nHowever, this widespread adoption is not without its challenges. A Boston Consulting Group study revealed that over half of executives surveyed are actively discouraging the use of generative AI due to a lack of understanding, whilst 37% are in a state of experimentation without proper policies or controls in place.\\\\n\\\\n1. Multimodal AI\\\\n----------------\\\\n\\\\n![Image 4: Youtube Placeholder](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/fD9SiYSpiwE/hqdefault.jpg)\\\\n\\\\nMultimodal AI represents a significant leap forward in AI, combining various data types such as text, images, audio, and video to create a more comprehensive understanding of the world. Unlike traditional unimodal systems that rely on a single data type, multimodal AI integrates diverse inputs, enabling it to perform complex tasks with greater accuracy and contextual awareness.\\\\n\\\\nAt its core, multimodal AI comprises three key components: the input module, fusion module, and output module. The input module consists of multiple unimodal neural networks, each handling a different data type. The fusion module then processes and aligns the information from each modality, employing techniques such as early fusion to concatenate raw data. More than half of them were most excited about object tracking and identification through computer vision.\\\\n\\\\nComputer vision is one way in which manufacturers are jumping into the [Industry 4.0 trend](https://voxel51.com/blog/how-computer-vision-is-changing-manufacturing-in-2023/).\\\\n\\\\n***![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/ujrdWXKoRNUgMpLudKKA)  \\\\nSearch interest for “AI in manufacturing” is up 480% in the past 5 years.***\\\\n\\\\n![undefined](https://cdn.buttercms.com/output=f:webp/ujrdWXKoRNUgMpLudKKA)\\\\n\\\\nThis is an industry that’s suffering from huge staffing shortages. Generative AI: From Hype to Essential Business Tool\\n-------------------------------------------------------\\n\\n![Image 4](https://www.neudesic.com/wp-content/uploads/in-blog-2024-AI-recap_AI-usage-increase-1024x398.png)\\n\\nIn just one year, from 2023 to 2024, generative AI dramatically shifted from a phase of rapid experimentation to a period of essential integrations into business operations. Furthermore, [IDC’s global survey](https://blogs.microsoft.com/blog/2024/11/12/idcs-2024-ai-opportunity-study-top-five-ai-trends-to-watch/) of enterprise organizations found that generative AI adoption is rapidly expanding with usage figures jumping from 55% in 2023 to 75%. Across industries, businesses began to embed AI into their core operations —particularly generative AI, which has rapidly taken hold in marketing and sales functions, where text-based communications and personalization serve as key drivers.  Companies in financial services, retail, and media have used generative AI to personalize customer experiences, reduce time-to-market, and streamline operations. In short, generative AI has transitioned from hype and proof-of-concept experiments to broader adoption, with companies emphasizing real-world implementations with tangible results.\\n\\n![Image 5](blob:http://localhost/ad49616dad180b71b08861433333c330)\\n\\nOpenAI’s ChatGPT played a key role in this surge. By December 2024, [ChatGPT reached 300 million weekly active users](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/12/04/openais-active-user-count-soars-to-300-million-people-per-week.html)—up from 200 million just four months prior. This explosive growth is a sign that generative AI is no longer a futuristic concept but an essential, versatile tool—one that’s quickly becoming more ingrained with our culture and society both professionally and personally—and it’s here to stay.\\n\\n2\\\\. Multimodal AI: Diverse Content from One Model\\n-------------------------------------------------\\n\\nAnother significant AI trend was the major advancements in multimodal AI—systems that understand and generate text, images, and audio from a single interface. Multimodal AI reduces the need for multiple specialized tools, making it easier for organizations to create and manage diverse content. Fun fact: the cover image of this blog was created using multimodal AI, courtesy of [Midjourney](https://www.midjourney.com/home).\\n\\nTwo major players, [OpenAI’s Sora](https://openai.com/index/learning-to-reason-with-llms/) and [Google’s Veo](https://deepmind.google/technologies/veo/veo-1/), captured the AI spotlight by providing impressive text-to-video capabilities. These tools promise to simplify content production for marketing, media, and education, allowing users to generate video content directly from a written prompt. The result? Faster production cycles and reduced creative bottlenecks.\\n\\n3\\\\. Reasoning AI: Solving Complex Problems\\n------------------------------------------\\n\\nOne of the most game-changing AI trends this year was the focus on building robust reasoning capabilities into AI systems. From new prompting methods to new model training techniques to new AI agent architectures, there have been many different approaches to building AI systems capable of solving increasingly complex tasks by iteratively planning, solving, and evaluating their work.\\n\\nModels with advanced reasoning capabilities, like  [OpenAI’s o1](https://openai.com/index/introducing-openai-o1-preview/), can already solve complex problems using logical steps that are similar to how humans think before responding to difficult questions. These capabilities will continue to be useful in fields like science, coding, math, law and medicine, allowing models to compare contracts, generate code and execute multistep workflows.\\n\\nMicrosoft’s [Phi models](https://news.microsoft.com/source/features/ai/the-phi-3-small-language-models-with-big-potential/) demonstrated how smaller models, when trained on high-quality data, can improve model performance and reasoning. Meanwhile, Orca and [Orca 2](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/blog/orca-2-teaching-small-language-models-how-to-reason/?msockid=1dbcd2bacdc96a0e1328c686cc736b2f) showed how synthetic data for post-training could improve model performance, making small models as capable as much larger language models. These training techniques help smaller models perform better on specialized tasks. Making models faster, better and more specialized will help create new and more useful AI experiences.\\n\\n4\\\\. AI Agents: From Reactive to Proactive\\n-----------------------------------------\\n\\nAI agents are swiftly evolving and transcending across differing business types and industries. [AI Agents extend the ability of LLMs](https://www.neudesic.com/blog/ai-agent-systems/) by equipping the model with tools and enabling it to act on a user’s behalf. Nearly [70% of Fortune 500 companies](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/investor/events/fy-2025/earnings-fy-2025-q1) already use Microsoft 365 Copilot to offload repetitive tasks like email triage and meeting notes via Teams. But Microsoft didn’t stop there. Microsoft introduced [new agents in Microsoft 365](https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/blog/microsoft365copilotblog/introducing-new-agents-in-microsoft-365/4296918) to streamline entire business processes, freeing up employees to focus on higher-value work.\\n\\n![Image 7](blob:http://localhost/f19e56331cf34a059197d5fb5b6082dc)\\n\\n[Neudesic’s AI Agent Assist](https://www.neudesic.com/blog/ai-powered-next-gen-agents-accelerating-onboarding-and-boosting-productivity-for-the-heartbeat-of-the-utility-call-center/) is one standout example. By using large language models (LLMs), AI Agent Assist provides call center agents with quick access to information and real-time support, which improves service quality by 40%. As a result, this allows call centers to transform customer service from reactive to proactive, boosting productivity and customer satisfaction.\\n\\nThese enhancements represent a significant leap in collaboration and information management, simplifying workflows and enhancing productivity across organizations.\\n\\n5\\\\. Cybersecurity: A Must-Have Strategy\\n---------------------------------------\\n\\nCybersecurity continued to be a pressing concern in 2024, with AI playing an increasingly pivotal role. According to the [Microsoft’s Digital Defense Report](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/security-insider/intelligence-reports/microsoft-digital-defense-report-2024#section-master-oc537b), AI integration into cyber defense improved threat detection and response. With over 176,000 incidents detected across 5,600 organizations in May alone, the scale of cyber threats underscored the urgency for advanced defenses.\\n\\nAI-powered tools enhanced capabilities like anomaly detection, threat analysis, and remediation, which are critical given the rising frequency and sophistication of attacks. Operational technology systems and AI itself were key targets for attackers, exploiting system vulnerabilities and enabling large-scale social engineering attacks. To combat this, businesses relied on AI to streamline processes like data labeling, policy enhancement, and monitoring generative AI applications to prevent oversharing or leaks.\\n\\nIn 2024, it became clear that AI-driven solutions weren’t just beneficial but were also critical to stay ahead of evolving cyber threats.\\n\\n6\\\\. Ethical and Responsible AI: Rules Get Real\\n----------------------------------------------\\n\\nWith AI becoming more prevalent, the conversation around ethics and regulation intensified in 2024. Governments worldwide introduced new AI regulations aimed at protecting privacy, ensuring accountability, and preventing misuse. In the US, there are more than [120 AI bills](https://www.whitecase.com/insight-our-thinking/ai-watch-global-regulatory-tracker-united-states) under review by the Congress.\\n\\nGovernments worldwide have introduced new laws designed to regulate AI technologies, particularly as it relates to data privacy and ethics. One of the most influential frameworks is the [European Union’s AI Act](https://hyperight.com/panel-european-artificial-intelligence-act-and-how-it-will-impact-data-and-ai-innovation-efforts-across-industries-and-functions/), which establishes clear rules for AI deployment in Europe. These regulations aim to protect users from risks related to AI, such as biased algorithms and data misuse. Companies operating in Europe will now need to ensure their AI tools meet compliance standards.\\n\\n7\\\\. AI at Work: Smarter and Faster Operations\\n---------------------------------------------\\n\\nAI is not only changing how businesses operate, but also redefining entire industries. From supply chain optimization to predictive analytics, AI tools helped companies make smarter and faster decisions.\\n\\n![Image 9](blob:http://localhost/f2865e73526a85a7b49fb80078261209)\\n\\n[Neudesic’s Supply Chain Control Tower](https://www.neudesic.com/blog/supply-chain-control-towers-benefits/) is a prime example. The platform provides organizations real-time visibility to manage and optimize their supply chain performance. This results in a 50% faster resolution time and a 20% cost reduction.\\n\\nIn the utilities sector, [Neudesic’s State of AI in Energy & Utilities Report](https://www.neudesic.com/ebook/state-of-ai-in-utilities/) revealed that AI adoption is driving modernization across utility companies, with 66% of organizations seeing operational improvements. From grid management to energy forecasting, AI-powered analytics are helping utilities become more agile and efficient.\\n\\n![Image 11](blob:http://localhost/44bd0dc0e095a0e9eb5ee79dbf45f0d4)\\n\\n8\\\\. AI in Science: Faster Scientific Discoveries, Better Healthcare\\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\\n\\nLastly, another notable AI trend is the significant advancements in science and medicine, improving both the efficiency of scientific discoveries and medical diagnostics and treatments.\\n\\nTake the [Da Vinci Surgical System](https://www.intuitive.com/en-us/patients/da-vinci-robotic-surgery/about-the-systems#:~:text=Your%20surgeon%20in%20control,or%20a%20few%20small%20incisions.&text=The%20da%20Vinci%20system%20is,back%20to%20what%20matters%20most.), which uses an AI robot to facilitate minimally invasive surgical procedures. By enhancing precision and control, the system helps surgeons perform complex operations with reduced recovery times for patients.\\n\\nIn medicine, models like [AlphaMissense](https://deepmind.google/discover/blog/a-catalogue-of-genetic-mutations-to-help-pinpoint-the-cause-of-diseases/) have improved genetic mutation classification. This technology increases the accuracy of genetic diagnostics, helping doctors predict the likelihood of diseases linked to genetic mutations. Such advancements are paving the way for more personalized medicine and earlier disease detection.\\n\\nLooking Ahead to 2025\\n---------------------\\n\\nThe 2024 AI trends showed us that AI isn’t just an experiment— it’s becoming an integral part of our business operations and in our society. Generative AI is now a daily tool, multimodal AI simplifies content creation, and reasoning AI solves real-world problems. With AI agents optimizing workflows and ethical AI guiding regulatory compliance, the future of AI feels more collaborative and grounded in responsibility.\\n\\nAs businesses continue to adopt AI for individuals Microsoft helped train and certify over the past year has been updated to 23 million and includes initiatives across Microsoft._\\n\\nIn 2024, generative AI emerged as a key driver for business outcomes across every industry. Already this new generation of AI is **[having an incredible impact](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/aka.ms/AIcustomersBlog___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjI0ZmFhZWY0OGM5YjcwMTU4OWNlY2JmYmNjZTI4MGZjOjY6MjI2YzoyYzY5NTMwNmZmNTM4YmZiYTIzOGE2ZDdhMjU3N2JjYWNhYWMwMDgyZDUwYmIxMjI2YmM1YTUwZjVmNThkNzMwOnA6RjpG)**on our world — yet companies and industries are just scratching the surface of what’s possible as they continue to develop new use cases across every role and function.\\n\\nTo help guide organizations on their AI transformation journey, Microsoft recently commissioned a new study through IDC, [**The Business Opportunity of AI**](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/info.microsoft.com/ww-landing-business-opportunity-of-ai.html___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6YzEzMzo1Y2E2ZTI1ZTgyNzNiMjQ0ZDhjOTJhMmRjNjA1YzRhNWIwNGU4MjcwZmRjNDc0YjBmZjFkNDhmZDg4MDNjM2YwOnA6VDpG). IDC’s findings show that when organizations truly commit to and invest in AI, the return on investment (ROI) potential grows significantly.\\n\\n[![Image 3: A graphic showing the IDC study’s top 3 key findings.](https://blogs.microsoft.com/wp-content/uploads/prod/2024/11/OMB-IDC_Social-Stat-2_1080x1920.jpg)](https://blogs.microsoft.com/wp-content/uploads/prod/2024/11/OMB-IDC_Social-Stat-2_1080x1920.jpg)\\n\\nAccording to IDC, the study’s findings reflect a tipping point as AI gains momentum across industries. As companies worldwide go deeper with AI, Microsoft customers continue to deploy innovative new solutions and discover how tools like [Copilot can transform their day-to-day work](https://news.microsoft.com/source/?post_type=features&p=8580). In telecommunications, [Lumen Technologies](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/news.microsoft.com/source/features/digital-transformation/the-only-way-how-copilot-is-helping-propel-an-evolution-at-lumen-technologies___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6OTdkYzoxYjM0ZDU2ZDhiNjFiNTkyNGRiMzZlZDkzOGE5M2U2NTRiZTgyYzRjYzA4MWJhZGFkNDFlODQ5ZWE0NWFkMGUwOnA6VDpG) estimates Copilot is saving sellers an average of four hours a week, equating to $50 million annually. In healthcare, [Chi Mei Medical Center](https://protect.checkpoint.com/v2/___https:/news.microsoft.com/source/asia/features/taiwan-hospital-deploys-ai-copilots-to-lighten-workloads-for-doctors-nurses-and-pharmacists___.YzJ1OndlY29tbXVuaWNhdGlvbnM6YzpvOjAxZWUwM2NlMzljZjdjMTA0YjIwYWViMmQ1MGYxYmU0OjY6OGVkMTo5YmJiOGY1MDE3Y2M4ZjIwYWIyNTU5OTgzN2M2ZDJiYzZlZDg4NDM4OGRhYjdhZjQ4MWMyMDVkZmFkZjIxYzljOnA6VDpG) doctors now spend 15 minutes instead of an hour writing medical reports, and nurses can document patient information in under five minutes.
